THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Charles Donnell Dublin, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-582
Heard November 8, 2005 â€“ Filed November 16, 2005Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Charles Donnell Dublin appeals his convictions in Aiken County for murder, assault and battery with intent to kill, armed robbery, attempted armed robbery, and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Dublin claims the trial court erred by admitting evidence of another crime in Orangeburg County.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS
Chris Corbitt, Chanelle Duncan (Corbittâ€™s girlfriend), Tony Rainey, and Thurmond â€œDukeâ€ Jones were watching TV in Corbittâ€™s trailer on April 10, 1998, when Dublin knocked on the door.Â  He said his name was â€œTimâ€ and asked to speak to Corbitt.Â  Ricky Tolliver waited outside.Â  Corbitt, a known drug dealer, agreed to let Dublin in.Â  Dublin entered the trailer, pulled out a pistol, and struck Jones on the head with it.Â  
Dublin asked Corbitt where he kept his money and drugs and then shot and killed Rainey.Â  Dublin also ordered Corbitt and Duncan to the floor and told Duncan to cover her head.Â  Dublin threatened to kill her unless Corbitt told him the location of his drugs and money.Â  
Corbitt told Dublin he could find the items outside under the trailer.Â  Dublin and Corbitt went to search for them while Tolliver watched the others.Â  When Dublin and Corbitt returned to the trailer to get a flashlight, Corbitt pushed Dublin away and attempted to flee.Â  Dublin fired at Corbitt, hitting him in the rear.Â  Dublin and Tolliver fled the scene.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge whose decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 121, 551 S.E.2d 240, 244 (2001).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.Â  State v. McLeod, 362 S.C. 73, 79, 606 S.E.2d 215, 219 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Error without prejudice does not warrant reversal.Â  State v. Locklair, 341 S.C. 352, 365, 535 S.E.2d 420, 427 (2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS

Dublin argues the trial judge erred by ruling that his counsel opened the door to otherwise inadmissible evidence when he sought to impeach Tolliver by asking him questions about his involvement in other crimes committed in Orangeburg County.
When a party opens the door to evidence, he cannot claim prejudice from its admission.Â  State v. Robinson, 305 S.C. 469, 474, 409 S.E.2d 404, 408 (1991); State v. Young, 364 S.C. 476, 485, 613 S.E.2d 386, 391 (Ct. App. 2005).
During the Stateâ€™s direct examination, Tolliver admitted pleading guilty to the crimes involved in this case but denied both participating in these crimes and knowing Dublin at the time of their commission.Â  The prosecutor then asked Tolliver whether he gave a statement and asked where he was when he gave it.Â  Tolliver said he gave a statement to the police in Orangeburg.Â  The State asked Tolliver if he testified in a trial in Orangeburg. Â Tolliver answered in the affirmative.Â  The prosecutor continued to ask about the contents of his statement.Â  Tolliver confirmed it was written by the police in Orangeburg.Â  At the end of the direct examination, Tolliver claimed he was innocent despite pleading guilty.Â  When asked why he would plead guilty for a crime he claimed he never committed, Tolliver said, â€œI have my reasons.â€Â  
On cross-examination, defense counsel also spent significant time attempting to impeach Tolliver.Â  Tolliver admitted to being arrested in 
Orangeburg County because of his involvement in Orangeburg crimes and to knowing the State could seek the death penalty against him.Â  Defense counsel then established the Orangeburg and Aiken authorities worked together and offered a plea bargain to Tolliver in exchange for his testimony.Â  Tolliver admitted pleading guilty to the Orangeburg and Aiken crimes in order to get a much shorter sentence.Â  
At the conclusion of Tolliverâ€™s cross-examination, the State requested a bench conference.Â  The State argued defense counsel opened the door when he asked Tolliver about the plea agreement and specific details of the Orangeburg murder.Â  Defense counsel argued he did not open the door but simply responded to the questions asked by the State in direct examination.Â  On re-direct, Tolliver confirmed Dublinâ€™s involvement in the Orangeburg crimes.Â  
Assuming arguendo that the trial court erred in holding defense counsel opened the door, we find the admission of that evidence did not prejudice Dublin. Â Error without prejudice does not warrant reversal.Â  Locklair, 341 S.C. at 365, 535 S.E.2d at 427.Â  An error is harmless if the defendantâ€™s guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other result could have been reached.Â  State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 53, 60, 609 S.E.2d 520, 524 (2005).
In the present case, the eyewitnesses to the crime (Corbitt, Jones, and Duncan) gave nearly identical testimony regarding the events of April 10, 1998.Â  Corbitt and Jones identified Dublin as the individual who shot Rainey.Â  Dublinâ€™s girlfriend at the time, Patricia Williams, testified about a prior conversation she had with Dublin in which he admitted his involvement in the Aiken murder and provided details only an active participant could know.Â  She also testified Dublin owned a nine-millimeter weapon at the time of the offenses. Â Her testimony is consistent with the evidence indicating nine-millimeter bullets were recovered from the body of Rainey.
AFFIRMED.Â  
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Rodriques Montez Pickens, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-583
Submitted September 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 16, 2005Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Joenathan Shelly Chaplin, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, of Columbia, and Druanne Dykes White, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Rodriques MontezPickens appeals his conviction for trafficking crack cocaine, arguing the trial court erred (1) in failing to suppress crack cocaine that he contends was seized in violation of the Fourth Amendment, (2) in charging the jury regarding constructive possession and knowledge, and (3) in allowing the State to introduce evidence that improperly commented on his character.Â  None of Pickensâ€™ arguments are preserved for appellate review. 
FACTS
On August 29, 2002, the Anderson County Sherrifâ€™s Office received a complaint that the driver of a black Lincoln Town car may be selling drugs in a neighborhood in Anderson County.Â  As a result, police officer Donnie Blassingame patrolled the neighborhood looking for a black Lincoln Town car.Â  Two other members of the department, Matthew Durham and Rodney Harbin, were in the same area and radioed to inform Blassingame they had spotted the car and followed it for several blocks.Â  
Blassingame then caught sight of the car and recognized the driver as Pickens.Â  Blassingame informed Durham that Pickens did not possess a valid driverâ€™s license, and Durham called dispatch to confirm Pickens did not have a valid driverâ€™s license.Â  Blassingame attempted to follow Pickens, but lost sight of him.Â  Later, Durham and Harbin saw the car parked in front of Boldenâ€™s Shop, an auto repair shop.Â  Durham saw Pickens get out of the car and open the hood.Â  Someone came out of the shop and looked under the hood with Pickens, then Pickens started walking across the four-lane highway in the direction of a restaurant.Â  
Dispatch informed the officers Pickens did not have a driverâ€™s license, so Durham and Harbin initiated contact with Pickens.Â  When prompted by the officerâ€™s questions, Pickens admitted he had been driving the car and did not possess a driverâ€™s license, so the officers arrested Pickens for driving without a license.Â  When asked for a vehicle registration card, Pickens indicted he was driving his motherâ€™s car but there might be a registration card in the car.Â  The officers escorted Pickens across the street to the auto repair shop where the car was parked.Â Â  The keys were still in the ignition, but the car was locked.Â  The car was equipped with a keypad entry system, but Pickens stated he did not know the code.Â  Durham â€œplayed aroundâ€ with the keypad, and the door opened.Â  Durham searched the car and found 91.88 grams of crack cocaine and scales in a shoe bag under the driverâ€™s seat.Â  When Blassingame arrived on the scene he conducted an inventory search of the car because the officerâ€™s had the car towed away and impounded.Â  
Pickens was charged with trafficking crack cocaine.Â  A jury found him guilty, and he was sentenced to eighteen years incarceration.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
 LAW/ANALYSIS     
Pickens argues the trial court erred in failing to suppress the crack cocaine that he contends was seized in violation of the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution. We find this issue is not preserved for our review. 
In order for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, it must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge.Â  Issues not raised and ruled upon in the trial court will not be considered on appeal.Â  State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 693-94 (2003).Â  â€œConstitutional arguments are no exception to the rule, and if not raised to the trial court are deemed waived on appeal.â€Â  State v. Varvil, 338 S.C. 335, 339, 526 S.E.2d 248, 250 (Ct. App. 2000).
 
Prior to the start of his trial, Pickens made a motion to exclude the crack cocaine the officers seized from the car.Â  Pickens argued the search was conducted without a warrant and was not a valid search incident to arrest.Â  The State argued the officers conducted a valid inventory search which would have led to the inevitable discovery of the crack cocaine regardless of whether the search incident to arrest was valid. Â In response, Pickensâ€™ counsel stated, â€œI donâ€™t take any issue with the inventory.â€Â  When the trial court questioned Pickensâ€™ counsel regarding the inevitable discovery issue, he stated, â€œ[T] hose issues will be developed with the testimony.Â  My objection was to the search incident to arrest.â€Â  The trial court denied the motion to suppress on the basis the inventory search was valid and did not rule on the legality of the search incident to arrest.Â  When the State sought to admit the crack cocaine into evidence at trial, Pickensâ€™ attorney acknowledged that he had no objection.Â  
Pickensâ€™ argument on appeal that the inventory search was illegal is not preserved because he never raised the issue to the trial judge.Â  Dunbar, 356 S.C. at 142, 587 S.E.2d at 693-94 (â€œIssues not raised and ruled upon in the trial court will not be considered on appeal.â€)Â  Additionally, although Pickens argued the search incident to arrest was invalid during the in limine hearing, he did not object when the crack cocaine was introduced into evidence.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  State v. Mueller, 319 S.C. 266, 268, 460 S.E.2d 409, 410 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œBecause the evidence developed during trial may warrant a change in the ruling, the losing party must renew his objection at trial when the evidence is presented in order to preserve the issue for appeal.â€) 
Pickens argues the trial courtâ€™s jury charge on constructive possession failed to adequately instruct the jury regarding the Stateâ€™s burden to prove Pickens had knowledge the crack cocaine was concealed in the car.Â  This issue is not preserved for review.Â  
After the trial judge gave the charge, he excused the jury and asked Pickens if he had any objections.Â  Pickensâ€™ attorney responded, â€œI have no additions or exceptions your honor.â€Â  Because Pickens failed to make any objection to the jury charge, we find the adequacy of the instruction is not preserved for our review.Â  State v. Avery, 333 S.C. 284, 296, 509 S.E.2d 476, 483 (1999) (holding a jury charge is not preserved for appellate review unless the party objects); see also Rule 20(b), SCRCP (â€œNotwithstanding any request for legal instructions, the parties shall be given the opportunity to object to the giving or failure to give an instruction before the jury retires, but out of the hearing of the jury. Any objection shall state distinctly the matter objected to and the grounds for objection. Failure to object in accordance with this rule shall constitute a waiver of objection.â€)Â Â Â  
Pickens argues the trial court erred in allowing the State to introduce evidence that improperly commented on his character.Â  This issue is not preserved for our review.Â  
At trial, Blassingame testified he was working the R Street neighborhood in Anderson â€œdue to a complaint we received from citizens of some unknown activities during the mornings, evenings, and late at night.â€Â  Pickens objected on the ground the testimony was hearsay, but the trial judge overruled the objection.Â  The next witness, Durham, testified that he and Harbin were investigating â€œcomplaints about a drug house located on R Street . . . we had talked to several people about the traffic going in and out all hours of the night.â€Â  The trial judge overruled Pickensâ€™ hearsay objection.Â  Durham continued his testimony as follows:Â  

  We talked to one neighbor who lived right in front of it.Â  Gave us a couple of tags on some vehicles they had observed coming in and out and staying short times.Â  And one of them was a Lincoln that was occupied by a black male that supposedly came to the residence, would stay only a few minutes and get back in the car and leave. Â 

Pickens once again objected to the testimony on the basis that it was hearsay.Â  The trial judge sustained the objection, ruling the statement was hearsay that went far beyond explaining why the officers were investigating the area.Â  Pickens did not make a motion to strike or request a curative instruction.Â  Durham then testified the house he was investigating â€œwas a house where crack cocaine was being sold out of.â€Â  Pickens objected, and the trial judge sustained the objection and instructed the jury to disregard the statement.Â  
On appeal, Pickens argues the aforementioned testimony, when taken together, constituted an improper comment on his character because the statements identified him, as the driver of the Lincoln Town car, as a suspected drug dealer.Â  However, Pickens did not object to the testimony on that ground at trial.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved for review on appeal.Â  State v. McCray, 332 S.C. 536, 542, 506 S.E.2d 301, 303 (1998) (holding a party cannot argue one ground at trial and another on appeal).Â  Accordingly, Pickensâ€™ conviction is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Responsible Economic Development, Carolyn JeBaily, Peggy Brown, Rachell Hyman, Walter Sallenger, Its Members and Directors, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        The Florence Consolidated Municipal Planning Commission, City of Florence, South Carolina, Hewitt Land Company, Inc., Trinity Evangelical Presbyterian Church, Inc., Wal-Mart Stores East, LP, and R. Jerry Hewitt, Respondents. 
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-584
Heard October 11, 2005 â€“ Filed November 16, 2005Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John J. Pringle, Jr., and John F. Beach, of Columbia, for Appellants.
Charlie James Blake, Jr., and D. Laurence McIntosh, of Florence; Frances Cantwell, William B. Regan, and James Dunbar Myrick, of Charleston; John Jay James, II, of Darlington, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Responsible Economic Development (RED) appeals a circuit court order upholding the Florence Consolidated Municipal Planning Commissionâ€™s (Planning Commission) approval of Wal-Mart Stores East, L.P.â€™s site development plan to construct a â€œSuperCenterâ€ and shopping complex in the City of Florence.Â  RED challenges the zonings of the two parcels of land on which the SuperCenter will be built and argues the Planning Commission failed to comply with state enabling legislation in approving Wal-Martâ€™s construction.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Pursuant to the South Carolina Local Government Planning Enabling Act of 1994 (Act),[1] Florence County and the municipalities within Florence County, including the City of Florence, formed the Planning Commission which designed a Comprehensive Plan (the Plan).Â  The County and City then adopted the Plan, together with a Consolidated Zoning Ordinance (Zoning Ordinance) and Land Development Regulations (Regulations).Â  
The Plan includes a land use element and incorporates a land use map depicting where certain types of uses should be encouraged and permitted.Â  The land use element of the Plan also incorporates a matrix, delineating compatible uses which correspond to the legend of use types shown on the land use map.Â  The Zoning Ordinance established various zoning districts, including residential, business, rural, and special purpose districts.Â  The Land Regulations control the subdivision and development of land.Â  
Â Trinity Evangelical Presbyterian Church, Inc. and R. Jerry Hewitt own the property at issue.[2]Â  These properties are located in Florence on Beltline Drive and Hoffmeyer Road, across the street from a high school and near a Samâ€™s Club.Â  The Planâ€™s land use map and matrix designate the properties for Business-Industrial uses, specifically including â€œBig Box Retail.â€Â  Originally, the Trinity property was zoned rural and residential, and the Hewitt property was not zoned.Â  
On March 16, 2000, Trinity submitted an application to amend the zoning of its property to general business.Â  On March 20, 2000, the Planning Commission posted signs on the Trinity property that advertised a public hearing on the proposed rezoning.Â  The Planning Commission also advertised the public hearing in a local weekly newspaper, the News Journal, on March 22, 2000.Â  On April 11, 2000, the Planning Commission held the public hearing.Â  The Florence City Council approved the rezoning request on June 12, 2000.Â  
On April 26, 2001, Hewitt submitted an application to the Planning Commission to annex his property to the City and to zone his property general business.Â  Notice of a public hearing appeared in the News Journal on May 2, 2001.Â  On May 3, 2001, the Planning Commission posted signs on the Hewitt property advertising the public hearing.Â  On May 22, 2001, the Planning Commission held the public hearing.Â  The Florence City Council approved the annexation and zoning of the Hewitt property on July 9, 2001.Â  
For purposes of this appeal, the ultimate zoning determination of the subject properties for commercial use was wholly consistent with the projected use as contemplated by the Plan.
Wal-Mart currently has an option to purchase the Trinity and Hewitt properties.Â  Wal-Mart intends to develop the property and construct a SuperCenter and shopping complex.Â  On July 22, 2003, Wal-Mart submitted a conceptual site plan to the Planning Commission.Â  
The members of RED own residential property in the Lakewood Subdivision near or adjacent to the proposed Wal-Mart development.Â  RED responded to Wal-Martâ€™s application with concerns about its effect on the Lakewood Subdivision.Â  In response to REDâ€™s concerns, Wal-Mart made several modifications to its conceptual site plan.Â  On October 29, 2003, after a series of correspondence between and among Wal-Mart, Wal-Martâ€™s engineers, the Planning Commission, and RED, the Planning Commission held a work session open to the public to discuss the major issues associated with the Wal-Mart development.Â  RED made a presentation at this work session.Â  On November 25, 2003, the Planning Commission approved Wal-Martâ€™s final site plan by a 7-2 vote.Â  
On December 23, 2003, RED filed a petition for judicial review of the decision of the Planning Commission and sought a declaratory order that the actions of the Planning Commission violated the substantive and procedural rights of its members.Â  On November 2, 2004, the circuit court issued an order dismissing the appeal and the petition for judicial review.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Â â€œIn the context of zoning, a decision of a reviewing body . . . will not be disturbed if there is evidence in the record to support its decision.â€Â  Rest. Row Assocs. v. Horry County, 335 S.C. 209, 215, 516 S.E.2d 442, 446 (1999); Peterson Outdoor Adver. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 327 S.C. 230, 235, 489 S.E.2d 630, 632 (1997).Â  â€œA court will refrain from substituting its judgment for that of the reviewing body, even if it disagrees with the decision.â€Â  Rest. Row Assocs., 335 S.C. at 216, 516 S.E.2d at 446; Peterson, 327 S.C. at 235, 489 S.E.2d at 632.Â  Zoning is a legislative function, and this court will refrain from second guessing a zoning authorityâ€™s decision if the decision is fairly debatable.Â  Petersen v. City of Clemson, 312 S.C. 162, 172, 439 S.E.2d 317, 323 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  â€œHowever, a decision of a municipal zoning board will be overturned if it is arbitrary, capricious, has no reasonable relation to a lawful purpose, or if the board has abused its discretion.â€Â  Rest. Row Assocs., 335 S.C. at 216, 516 S.E.2d at 446; Peterson, 327 S.C. at 235, 489 S.E.2d at 633.Â  This court is not permitted to disturb any of the circuit courtâ€™s findings of fact if there is any evidence to support them.Â  Petersen, 312 S.C at 169, 439 S.E.2d at 322 (Ct. App. 1993) (citing Bishop v. Hightower, 292 S.C. 358, 356 S.E.2d 420 (Ct. App. 1987).
LAW/ANALYSIS
RED argues the circuit court erred in upholding the Planning Commissionâ€™s decision to approve the Wal-Mart SuperCenter because: (1) the zoning of the Trinity and Hewitt properties was illegally accomplished; and (2) the Zoning Ordinance and Regulations do not comply with the Act or the Comprehensive Plan.Â  We disagree.
The circuit court found REDâ€™s challenges were barred as filed outside the applicable statute of limitations.Â  We find no error in this determination.Â  South Carolina Code Ann. Section 6-29-760(D) (2004) precludes any challenge to the adequacy of notice or validity of a zoning regulation or map, or amendment to it sixty days after the decision of the governing body, if there has been substantial compliance with the notice requirements of the Act or with locally established procedures.Â  REDâ€™s challenges came more than two years after the properties were rezoned.Â  Thus, RED had the burden of showing that the Planning Commission failed to substantially comply with the notice requirements of the Act or the Zoning Ordinance.Â  We find, as the circuit court did, that substantial compliance was met.
I.Â  Substantial Compliance with Notice Requirements
1.Â  Newspaper of General Circulation
Both section 9.5 of the Zoning Ordinance and South Carolina Code Ann. Section 6-29-760(A) (2004) provide that, prior to rezoning property, the Planning Commission must hold a public hearing and advertise the time and place of the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation. Â In the present case, the notice of the zoning applications was published in the News Journal, a free publication that has a circulation of 25,000.Â  RED contends the News Journal does not meet the â€œnewspaper of general circulationâ€ requirement because notice may have been more effective if run in a paper with a larger circulation and with paid subscribers.Â Â Â  
We agree with the circuit courtâ€™s finding that the News Journal is a newspaper of general circulation as required by the Act and the Zoning Ordinance.Â  â€œFor a publication to be considered a newspaper of general circulation, it must contain items of general interest to the public.â€Â  58 Am. Jur. 2d Newspapers, Periodicals, and Press Associations Â§ 37 (2005).Â  RED makes no contention the News Journal does not contain items of general interest to the public.Â  Further, neither the Zoning Ordinance nor the Act require publication in the largest newspaper or in a paper with paid subscribers.Â  
2.Â  Signage
South Carolina Code Ann. Section 6-29-760(A) (2004) requires that the affected property be posted with conspicuous notice visible from each right of way upon which the property abuts.Â  Section 9.5 of the Zoning Ordinance is analogous to section 6-29-760(A) with the added requirement that one notice is to be posted for every 200 feet of road frontage, advising of the nature of the change, and the time, date, and place of the hearing.Â  In this case, the signage posted on the two properties contained a large â€œZâ€, stated â€œZONING CHANGE PROPOSEDâ€, and included a telephone number that members of the public could use to request more information.[3]Â  While exacting compliance with the Zoning Ordinance was lacking here, we concur with the circuit court in finding that substantial compliance was demonstrated.Â  
South Carolina case law does not specifically define substantial compliance in the context of S.C. Code Ann. Section 6-29-760(D) (2004).Â  However, American jurisprudence generally holds substantial compliance is met if the purpose of the statute is achieved.Â  See James v. County of Kitsap, 115 P.3d 286, 293 (Wash. 2005) (substantial compliance means a court should determine whether a statute has been followed sufficiently so as to carry out the intent for which the statute was adopted); Iowa State Bank & Trust Co. v. Michel, 683 N.W.2d 95, 105 (Iowa 2004) (in deciding whether a party has substantially complied with a statutory requirement, the court evaluates whether the asserted compliance assures that the reasonable objectives of the statute will be met); Rosenblatt v. City of Houston, 31 S.W.3d 399, 404 (Tex. Ct. App. 2000) (â€œSubstantial compliance has been defined to mean performance of the essential requirements of a statute.â€); Morrow v. Bobbit, 943 S.W.2d 384, 389 (Tenn. Ct. App. 1996) (substantial compliance is met when it is reasonable to conclude that the objective sought by the statute has been fully attained); Thrash v. City of Asheville, 393 S.E.2d 842, 845 (N.C. 1990) (â€œSubstantial compliance means compliance with the essential requirements of the statute.â€); Sabatini v. Jayhawk Const. Co., Inc., 520 P.2d 1230, 1234 (Kan. 1974) (â€œSubstantial compliance requires compliance in respect to the essential matters necessary to assure every reasonable objective of the statute.â€); Brow v. Sherwin-Williams Co., 109 N.E.2d 864, 866-67 (Ohio 1952) (the requirements of a procedural statute are met when the municipality substantially complies with the statuteâ€™s procedural mandates, which requires the municipality to act in a way to achieve the purpose of the statute).Â  
The decisions in South Carolina are in full accord with the above cited cases.Â  See, e.g., Quality Towing, Inc. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 345 S.C. 156, 164-65, 547 S.E.2d 862, 866 (2001) (looking to the clear language and express purpose of a federal act to determine whether substantial compliance occurred); Davis v. NationsCredit Fin. Servs. Corp., 326 S.C. 83, 86, 484 S.E.2d 471, 472 (1997) (looking to the purpose of a statute in determining whether substantial compliance occurred).Â  
In the present case, the objectives sought to be achieved by the notice requirements were, in fact, met.Â  The purpose of the posting requirement is to put interested parties on notice of a public hearing.Â  The record reveals that an official of the high school across the street knew to inquire further about the Trinity zoning change because a representative was present at the public hearing.Â  Additionally, as to the Hewitt zoning, a number of telephone calls were received from members of the public, inquiring about the change.Â  Accordingly, there is evidence to support the circuit courtâ€™s determination that the technical noncompliance of the signage does not defeat a finding of substantial compliance.Â  See Morrow, 943 S.W.2d at 389 (Tenn. Ct. App. 1996).
3.Â  Notice to Adjacent Landowners
Finally, RED contends the Planning Commission did not provide notice to adjoining landowners, as required by the Act and the Zoning Ordinance.Â  We, however, join the circuit court in finding that REDâ€™s argument has no basis in law.Â  Neither the Act nor the Zoning Ordinance requires individual, written notice of the zoning application.Â  In any event, RED cannot overcome the fact of substantial compliance.
II.Â  Â Â  Consideration of Surrounding Land Uses
RED contends the Planning Commission failed to consider the current use of land surrounding the Trinity property during its rezoning and the Hewitt property during its annexation and zoning.Â  As noted above, we find that this argument is barred as filed outside the applicable statute of limitations, South Carolina Code Ann. Section 6-29-760(D) (2004).Â  Regardless, we agree with the circuit courtâ€™s conclusion that this argument fails on the merits.Â  
The record reveals surrounding uses were identified with respect to the zoning of both the Trinity and Hewitt properties.Â  The graphics and pictures attached to the staff reports show the uses abutting the Trinity and Hewitt properties, geographically and by legend, to include subdivision use.Â  The Planning Commission, therefore, did consider the use of the land surrounding the Trinity and Hewitt properties.Â  The fact that this â€œconsiderationâ€ did not culminate in the result sought by RED does not advance its position on appeal. 
III.  Alleged Failure to Comply with the Act and the Comprehensive Plan in Zonings
RED contends the rezoning of the Trinity property and annexation and zoning of the Hewitt property must be set aside for failing to comply with the Act and the Plan.Â  Again, we find this argument barred under South Carolina Code Ann. Section 6-29-760(D) (2004).Â  However, this argument also fails on the merits.
The circuit court found that the Zoning Ordinance, Regulations, and Plan are all consistent.Â  We agree.Â  As noted above, the land use map and matrix incorporated by the Plan designate the Hewitt property and Trinity property for Business-Industrial uses, including â€œBig Box Retail.â€Â  The zoning of these properties is â€œB-3,â€ general business.Â  The ultimate zoning determinationâ€”for commercial useâ€”tracks the Planâ€™s projected use for these properties.Â  Because there is consistency between the Plan and the subsequent zoning, we need not address any phantom dispute or conflict between the Plan and the Zoning Ordinance.Â  REDâ€™s argument is without merit.Â Â Â  
Finally, in view of this courtâ€™s deferential standard of review and the fact that we find the Planning Commissionâ€™s decision at least fairly debatable, we refrain from second guessing its decision.Â  See Petersen, 312 S.C. at 165, 439 S.E.2d at 320.
IV.Â  Alleged Failure to Consider and Apply the Comprehensive Plan to the Wal-Mart Project
RED contends the Planning Commission failed to consider and apply the Plan in approving the Wal-Mart project.Â  We disagree.Â  
First, we find that the Plan is consistent with the Wal-Mart project.Â  As discussed above, the Plan originally designated the property on which the SuperCenter will be built as appropriate for Business-Industrial use.Â  The SuperCenter fits that described use.Â  Second, the circuit court found no evidence that the Planning Commission acted arbitrarily or capriciously in approving the Wal-Mart project.Â  The record reveals this to be true as it provides the Wal-Mart project was granted only after thorough study, and after modifications were made by Wal-Mart in response to input by staff, the public, and members of RED.Â  
CONCLUSION
We join the circuit court in finding that the Planning Commission substantially complied with the notice requirements of the Act and Zoning Ordinance in rezoning the Trinity property and annexing and zoning the Hewitt property.Â  Therefore, REDâ€™s challenge to this decision is procedurally barred pursuant to section 6-29-760(D) of the South Carolina Code (2004).Â  In addition, we concur in the finding that the Planning Commission did not act arbitrarily, capriciously, or in abuse of its discretion in approving Wal-Martâ€™s application.Â  The circuit court order dismissing REDâ€™s petition for judicial review is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ. concur.

[1] Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-310, et seq.
[2] Â Trinity and Hewitt own separate parcels of the property at issue.Â  The parcels â€œownedâ€ by Hewitt are titled in either R. Jerry Hewitt individually or in Hewitt Land Company, Inc., an entity owned by R. Jerry Hewitt.Â  
[3] Â The Planning Commission uses the same signs for every zoning change and has done so for a number of years.Â  Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Newberry Electric Cooperative, Inc., Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        City of Newberry, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Newberry County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-585
Heard September 9, 2005 â€“ Filed November 16, 2005Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Eugene C. Griffith, Jr., Rushing & Griffith, P.C., of Newberry, Robert T. Bockman, McNair Law Firm, PA, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        C. Pinckney Roberts, Pinckney Roberts, Attorney & Counselor at Law, of Columbia, Thomas H. Pope, III, Pope and Hudgens, P.A., of Newberry, for Respondent.
        James M. Brailsford, III, of Edisto Island, 7805 Russell Creek Dr., for Amicus Curiae. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Newberry Electric Cooperative, Inc., (the Cooperative) brought an action pursuant to section 58-27-1360 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004), seeking to require the City of Newberry (the City) to purchase certain electric facilities in an area newly annexed by the City.Â  After an arbitration panel determined the fair value of the facilities, the City brought a declaratory judgment action in circuit court seeking a declaration of its legal rights and obligations under section 58-27-1360 as applied to the arbitration decision.Â  The City now appeals the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of its action and denial of its petition for declaratory judgment.Â  We affirm.
FACTS

In March 2003, the Cooperative served the City with its Notice of Exercise of Right to Compel Purchase of Facilities and Property and Payment of Just Compensation and Notice to Appoint Representative.Â  The Cooperative served the notice to invoke its rights under section 58-27-1360 to receive just compensation from the city for certain facilities owned by the Cooperative and within an area annexed by the City.Â  The notice identified five project areas for which the Cooperative sought compensation and set forth an amount of approximately $6 million for compensation.Â  
The City filed a Return to Notice.Â  It responded with its own figure for just compensation of approximately $113,000.Â  The two sides were unable to reach a settlement regarding the amount of just compensation for the affected facilities.
The Cooperative and the City jointly moved the circuit court for an order of arbitration with certain procedures and conditions agreed upon by the parties.Â  The arbitration panel would consist of three individuals and would determine the amount of just compensation owed to the Cooperative by the City.Â  The order provided in part:

  (e)Â Â Â Â  the decision of the Arbitration Panel shall be determined by the vote of at least two of the arbiters, and the written decision of the Panel shall consist only of the following:
  â€œJust compensation to Newberry Electric Cooperative, Inc. (including reasonable expenses, engineersâ€™ and attorneysâ€™ fees per S.C. Code Â§ 58-27-1260) is determined to be $_________.â€Â  (Emphasis added).Â  

The above amount was the only determination to be made by the arbitration panel pursuant to the consent order of the parties.Â  The provision did not require any explanation of the amount or how it was derived.Â  The parties each provided the arbitration panel with documentary exhibits and oral argument.Â  
The panel allowed the parties to submit proposed decisions and awards.Â  The Cityâ€™s proposal allowed for just compensation of $282,989.Â  The proposal also set forth specific findings regarding the facilities, the reintegration of the Cooperativeâ€™s facilities, and the impact on the customers served by the affected facilities.Â  The Cooperative also submitted a detailed proposal including findings regarding the facilities and customers.Â  The Cooperative suggested a just compensation award of $6,243,299.69.Â  
In September 2003, the panel returned a decision and award in the format provided by the order and listed the amount of just compensation as $3,853,639.14.Â  The panel did not provide any explanation as to how the figure was derived or what the Cooperative was required to expend on reintegration of the facilities.Â  The panel did exactly as asked by the parties and only calculated a figure for just compensation.Â  Neither the City nor the Cooperative asked the panel to clarify the award or filed an appeal from this award.Â  Furthermore, neither party asked the circuit court to vacate or modify the award pursuant to the Uniform Arbitration Act, sections 15-48-10 through 15-48-240 of the South Carolina Code (2005).
Instead, the City brought this declaratory judgment action, seeking a declaration of its rights and obligations under section 58-27-1360 by the circuit court.Â  In the alternative, the City asked the circuit court to remand the issue to the arbitration panel for â€œclarification, amendment or alteration of the Decision and Award sufficient to resolve the factual issues concerning facilities, properties, customers, loss of revenue and reintegration . . . .â€Â  The Cooperative moved to dismiss the action.
The circuit court issued an order denying the petition for declaratory judgment and dismissing the action.Â  The court found the award was in precisely the form of decision set forth in the consent order and the City had waived any right to object to the form and nature of the award.Â  It held the award was final and binding and not subject to collateral attack under the guise of a declaratory judgment action.Â  Finally, the court found the Cooperative brought the action for just compensation, specifically setting forth the facilities, properties, reintegration, and customers involved.Â  The court concluded the Arbitration Panel had at least a barely colorable factual and legal basis upon which to find that the Cooperativeâ€™s plan was reasonable and that the just compensation due to the Cooperative was in the amount of $3,853,639.14.Â  The City filed a Motion to Alter or Amend Judgment, which the circuit court denied.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The City argues the trial court erred in failing to remand the arbitration decision to the arbitration panel for clarification of the rights and obligations of the parties under its decision.Â  The City maintains section 58-27-1360 contains several specific factors to consider in reaching just compensation, and the trial court should have required a specific determination of the amount allocated to the various factors.Â  We disagree.
Section 58-27-1360 lists three components of the â€œjust compensationâ€ a city must pay a cooperative:Â  (a) the cost of the facilities being acquired; (b) the cost of reintegrating the system, and (c) an additional amount in recognition of lost revenue from consumers the cooperative loses in the transaction.Â Â  The statute does not require the arbitrators to make specific finding of fact for each component or delineate the amount it awarded for each factor.Â  See Taylor v. Atlantic Beach Election Commâ€™n, 363 S.C. 8, 15, 609 S.E.2d 500, 503 (2005) (finding circuit court did not err in refusing to remand matter to election commission for more definitive findings and rulings in a written order where election statute does not require a written order containing findings of fact or conclusions of law).Â  Furthermore, the consent order compelling arbitration did not require such findings.Â  Rather, it limited the arbitration panelâ€™s written decision, providing:Â  â€œthe written decision of the Panel shall consist only of the following: â€˜Just compensation to Newberry Electric Cooperative, Inc. . . . is determined to be $_______.â€™â€Â  (Emphasis added).Â  The arbitration panelâ€™s decision was in this exact form, inserting the dollar amount for just compensation.Â  
Although the City now claims to be unsatisfied with the form of this ruling, it did not seek clarification of the award from the arbitration panel.Â  The Uniform Arbitration Act sets forth a procedure for a party to seek clarification of a ruling.Â  S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-100 (2005).Â  Our supreme court held if a party submits an issue for arbitration and the arbitrators fail to clearly rule on the issue in the award, the party must request the arbitrators address the issue pursuant to section15-48-100.Â  Renaissance Enterprises, Inc. v. Ocean Resorts, Inc., 330 S.C. 13, 19, 496 S.E.2d 858, 861 (1998).Â  If a party fails to do so, the issue will not be preserved for further review.Â  Id.Â  at 19-20, 496 S.E.2d at 862.Â  Even if the Uniform Arbitration Act does not apply, the parties expressly adopted the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure to apply to the arbitration.Â  Thus, under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, the City may have asked for clarification of the order.Â  It is well established that an issue not ruled on by the trial judge is not preserved for appellate review unless the issue is raised in a post-trial motion.Â  Rickborn v. Liberty Life Ins. Co., 321 S.C. 291, 468 S.E.2d 292 (1996).Â  Like other civil proceedings, the arbitrators must rule on the issue in order to preserve it for further review.Â  Renaissance, 330 S.C. at 20, 496 S.E.2d at 862.Â  
The City, however, failed to avail itself of either procedure to seek clarification of the arbitration panelâ€™s decision directly from the panel.Â  Rather, it filed this declaratory judgment action.Â  Pursuant to section 58-27-1360, the arbitration panelâ€™s â€œdecision on just compensation, . . . is final and binding on the parties.â€Â  In its brief, the City stresses that it is not seeking judicial review of the arbitration panelâ€™s decision. Rather, the City appears to be attempting to collaterally attack the decision of the arbitration panel by means of a declaratory judgment action.Â Â  Appellate courts have â€œrefused to allow collateral attacks under the guise of a declaratory judgment action upon the final judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction.â€Â  Charleston County Sch. Dist. v. S.C. State Ports Auth., 283 S.C. 48, 52320 S.E.2d 727, 730 (Ct. App. 1984) (citing Henry v. Cottingham, 253 S.C. 286, 170 S.E.2d 387 (1969); Jackson v. Cannon, 266 S.C. 198, 222 S.E.2d 494 (1976)).Â  We agree with the circuit court that the City waived the right to object to the form and nature of the award.Â  We find the City cannot now challenge the merits of the award by the arbitration panel.
As to the Cityâ€™s desire to have the circuit court remand the decision to the panel for further explanation, we find the court properly denied the petition.Â  The decision of the panel fully complied with the mandate issued by the circuit court and was in the form agreed upon by the parties.Â  See Pittman Mortgage Co., Inc. v. Edwards, 327 S.C. 72, 76-77, 488 S.E.2d 335, 338 (1997) (â€œA party may not attempt to relitigate the merits of the arbitratorsâ€™ resolution of the arbitrable issues under the guise of questioning the arbitratorsâ€™ power.â€).Â  The City neither asked the panel for further consideration of their decision nor for clarification of their decision.Â  As stated above, the determination of compensation in this condemnation case was properly made by the arbitration panel and not appropriately challenged.Â  Accordingly, any declaration of the rights and obligations by the circuit court would constitute an advisory opinion and is prohibited.Â  See Blue Ridge Elec. Coop. v. Combined Util. Sys. of City of Easley, 279 S.C. 135, 139-40, 303 S.E.2d 91, 94 (1983) (holding â€œdeclaratory judgment action must involve an actual justiciable controversyâ€ and case should be dismissed where â€œit seeks merely an advisory opinion.â€).Â  
CONCLUSION
We hold the arbitration decision is final and binding on the parties.Â  As the circuit court properly concluded, there is no reason to require further explanation from the panel regarding its award when the panel rendered the decision requested by both parties.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court dismissing the declaratory judgment action is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.Â

title: Hendrix v. Hollingsworth
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Waymon Hendrix, Employee, Appellant,
v.
J.D. Hollingsworth, Employer and Hartford Underwriters Ins. Co., Carrier,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenville County
G. Edward Welmaker, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.2005-UP-587
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 17, 2005Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Andrew C. Barr, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Duke K. McCall, Jr., of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this workersâ€™ compensation action, the single commissioner determined Waymon Hendrixâ€™s claim was barred by the applicable statute of limitations, S.C. Code Ann. Section 42-15-40 (Supp. 2004), and there was no evidence of estoppel or waiver on the part of Employer J. D. Hollingsworth (Hollingsworth).Â  An appellate panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (the Commission) adopted the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  The circuit court affirmed.Â  Hendrix appeals, arguing the discovery rule applies to his case, and consequently, his claim is within the statute of limitations.Â  Hendrix further contends the doctrine of estoppel bars Hollingsworth from asserting the statute of limitations.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities:
1.Â  We find Hendrixâ€™s assignment of error in connection with the discovery rule was first raised to the circuit court and not the Commission.Â  Accordingly, it is not preserved for review by this court.Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilkie, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); Rodney v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 517, 466 S.E.2d 357, 358 (1996) (â€œArguments not raised to the workersâ€™
compensation commission or to the circuit court are not preserved for appeal.â€).Â  Nevertheless, assuming the applicability of the discovery rule, we find application of the rule would not alter the ultimate resultâ€”Hendrix filed his claim outside the statute of limitations.Â  The record reveals Hendrix was diagnosed early on with the injury that gave rise to his claim.Â  On at least three separate occasionsâ€”in December 1999, January 2000, and February 2000â€”Hendrix was diagnosed with a finding of â€œpositive impingementâ€ to his right shoulder.Â  Thus, the statute of limitations had run prior to the filing of the claim in May 2002.Â  Mauldin v. Dyna-Color/Jack Rabbit, 308 S.C. 18, 20, 416 S.E.2d 639, 640 (1992) (under the discovery rule, the statute of limitations begins to run from the date a claimant either knew or should have known of his compensable injury); Johnston v. Bowen, 313 S.C. 61, 64, 437 S.E.2d 45, 47 (1993) (injured party must act with some promptness where facts and circumstances of the injury would put a person of common knowledge and experience on notice that some right of his had been invaded or that some claim against another party might exist; statute of limitations begins to run from this point and not when advice of counsel is sought or full-blown theory of recovery is developed).Â  
2.Â  We find the substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s rejection of Hendrixâ€™s reliance on the principles of estoppel and waiver to defeat the statute of limitations.Â  An appellate court must affirm the findings of the Commission if they are supported by substantial evidence. 
Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 289, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610-11 (Ct. App. 2004); Grant v. Grant Textiles, 361 S.C. 188, 191, 603 S.E.2d 858, 859 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œA reviewing court will not overturn a decision by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission unless the determination is unsupported by substantial evidence or is affected by an error of law.â€).Â  In regards to his injury, Hendrix testified he believed he â€œwas being taken care ofâ€ by Hollingsworth because he was sent to the company doctor, and all of his medical bills and mileage costs associated with his injury were paid for by Hollingsworth.Â  Additionally, Hendrix testified he was never informed by anyone at Hollingsworth that he needed to file anything, and he was simply â€œunder the impression that [he] was under Workmanâ€™s Comp.â€Â  There is no testimony in the record that any representative of Hollingsworth specifically told Hendrix that he would be taken care of.Â  See Hopkins v. Floydâ€™s Wholesale, 299 S.C. 127, 129, 382 S.E.2d 907, 908 (1989) (an employer may be estopped from asserting the statute of limitations as a bar to subsequently filed workersâ€™ compensation suits if the employer induces the claimant to believe that the claim is compensable and will be taken care of without its being filed with the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission within the period limited); see also Poole v. E. I. Du Pont Nemours & Co., 227 S.C. 232, 87 S.E.2d 640, 641 (1955) (South Carolina adheres to the general principle that waiver or estoppel will arise from conduct on the part of the employer or carrier from which it may be reasonably inferred that the claimant was misled or deceived, whether intentionally or not, and thereby failed to file his claim within the statute of limitations). 
 AFFIRMED.

STILWELL, KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

Sandra Crowder, Appellant,
v.
Raymond E. Franklin, Laurens County Sheriffâ€™s Department, and County of Laurens,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-588
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 17, 2005Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Theo W. Mitchell, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Andrew F. Lindemann, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Sandra Crowder brought this action against Raymond E. Franklin, the Laurens County Sheriffâ€™s Department, and Laurens County (Defendants), asserting claims for (1) false arrest and imprisonment; (2) violation of her rights under the South Carolina Constitution; and (3) negligent hiring, training, and supervision.Â  The suit arises out of Crowderâ€™s arrest for public disorderly conduct at the Laurens County Speedway on June 10, 2000.[1]Â  The trial court dismissed Franklin and the Sheriffâ€™s Department from the action based on improper service and granted summary judgment in favor of Laurens County.Â  Crowder appeals.
We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities:Â  
As to Issue I regarding the grant of a motion to dismiss Franklin and the Sheriffâ€™s Department:Â  Rule 4(d)(5), SCRCP (stating service upon a state officer or agency shall be made â€œby delivering a copy of the summons and complaint to such officer or agency and by sending a copy of the summons and complaint by registered or certified mail to the Attorney General at Columbiaâ€); Cone v. Nettles, 308 S.C. 109, 417 S.E.2d 523 (1992) (holding sheriffs and deputies are state, not county, officials).
As to Issue II regarding the grant of a motion for summary judgment in favor of Laurens County:Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP (Under the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, summary judgment is appropriate â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€); Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 42, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997) (â€œIn determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€); L & W Wholesale, Inc. v. Gore, 305 S.C. 250, 253, 407 S.E.2d 658, 659 (Ct. App. 1991) (stating at the summary judgment stage of litigation, the trial court does not weigh conflicting evidence regarding a disputed material fact and does not make credibility determinations); see also Rule 208(b)(1)(B), SCACR (â€œOrdinarily, no point will be considered which is not set forth in the statement of the issues on appeal.â€); Solley v. Weaver, 247 S.C. 129, 131, 146 S.E.2d 164, 165 (1966) (â€œWe have held in many cases that every ground of appeal ought to be so distinctly stated that the Court may at once see the point which it is called upon to decide without having to â€˜grope in the darkâ€™ to ascertain the precise point at issue.Â  The object of an exception is to present some distinct principle or question of law which the appellant claims to have been violated by the Court in the trial of the case from which the appeal is taken, and to present it in such form that it may be properly reviewed.â€); Fields v. Melrose Ltd. Partnership, 312 S.C. 102, 439 S.E.2d 283 (Ct. App. 1993) (stating an issue is deemed abandoned on appeal and not presented for review where it is argued in a short, conclusory statement without supporting authority).
AFFIRMED.[2]
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[2]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Preston v. Charleston County Sheriff's Department
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Scott Douglas Preston, Respondent,
v.
Charleston County Sheriff's Department and South Carolina Department of Education, Transportation Division,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â DanielÂ  F.Â  Pieper, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 05-UP-589
Heard October 05, 2005 â€“ Filed November 18, 2005 Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Christopher L. Murphy and James A. Stuckey, Jr., of Charleston, for Appellants
George J. Morris, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The Charleston County Sheriffâ€™s Department and South Carolina Department of Education, Transportation Division (Appellants) appeal from a jury verdict awarding Scott Preston damages for injuries he sustained in a traffic accident with a school bus.Â  Appellants argue the trial court erred in permitting a police officer, qualified as an expert, to give opinion testimony regarding speed.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
This action arises out of a traffic accident that occurred on the morning of February 26, 2001.Â  Preston was driving his motorcycle when he approached an intersection where traffic was being directed by a crossing guard.Â  Meanwhile, a South Carolina Department of Education school bus approached the intersection and was directed by the crossing guard to proceed through the intersection.Â  Several witnesses later testified the school bus entered the intersection without properly stopping at the stop sign.Â  Although Preston attempted to avoid a collision by applying his brakes, he crashed into the side of the school bus.Â  Preston suffered multiple serious injuries, including a fractured left arm and dislocated wrist, a broken collarbone, multiple broken ribs, collapsed lungs, two broken legs, broken facial bones, and a metal rod was lodged in his right arm.Â  As a result of these injuries, Preston lost feeling in a portion of his face and has permanent metal supports in his legs and face. 
Preston filed a negligence action against Appellants seeking damages for injuries he sustained in the accident.Â  A jury found Preston was not entitled to damages because he was more than half at fault for the collision, but the trial judge, acting as the thirteenth juror, ordered a new trial.Â  During the subsequent trial, much testimony focused on Prestonâ€™s speed immediately preceding the accident.Â  Preston testified he was traveling over the 35 mph speed limit.Â  Angela Champion, who was driving the car traveling behind Preston, estimated Prestonâ€™s speed between 45 and 50 mph, and another witness, Angela Spalviero, testified Preston was â€œflying.â€ 
Preston proffered the testimony of the police officer who investigated the accident, Murray Abramson.Â  Appellants objected to Abramson giving an opinion regarding Prestonâ€™s speed, so the trial court examined Abramson outside of the juryâ€™s presence.Â  Abramson testified that based on his education and experience, he believed himself capable of estimating the probable speed of the motorcycle.Â  
After qualifying him as an expert, the trial court allowed Abramson to offer his opinion regarding the motorcycleâ€™s speed prior to the accident.Â  At the scene of the accident, Abramson measured the motorcycleâ€™s skid marks at 90 feet, 11 inches.Â  Using a chart to estimate speed based on the length of skid marks, reaction time, and braking time, Abramson testified Preston was traveling at least 45 mph.Â  In response, James Jur, an accident reconstruction expert, offered his opinion that Preston was traveling between 53 and 61 mph before applying his brakes.Â  Jur explained that based on the length of the skid marks, the motorcycleâ€™s minimum speed was 45mph, but that his calculations took into account other factors not represented on the chart Abramson used.
The jury returned a verdict in the amount of $707,000.Â  However, the jury found Preston was 50% at fault for the accident, so the trial judge reduced the award by 50%.Â  The trial judge further reduced the damage award to $300,000, the statutory maximum as provided by the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-120 (2005).Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants argue the trial court judge abused his discretion by qualifying Abramson as an expert and allowing him to give an opinion as to the motorcycleâ€™s speed preceding the collision. We disagree.
Rule 702, SCRE permits expert opinion testimony and articulates the standard for admissibility as follows: â€œIf scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, a witness qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education, may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise.â€Â  Qualification of an expert and the admission or exclusion of his testimony is within the sound discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Goode, 305 S.C. 176, 177-78, 406 S.E.2d 391, 392-93 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  â€œThere is no abuse of discretion as long as the witness has acquired by study or practical experience such knowledge of the subject matter of his testimony as would enable him to give guidance and assistance to the jury in resolving a factual issue which is beyond the scope of the juryâ€™s good judgment and common knowledge.â€Â  Goode, 305 S.C. at 178, 406 S.E.2d at 393.Â  There is no exact requirement concerning how knowledge or skill must be acquired.Â  Id.Â  In order for this court to reverse a judgment for an alleged error in the exclusion or admission of evidence, the complaining party must prove both the error of the ruling and resulting prejudice.Â  Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 525, 595 S.E.2d 817, 825 (Ct. App. 2004).
Many South Carolina decisions have excluded the opinions of investigating police officers in automobile accident cases.Â  Gulledge v. McLaughlin, 328 S.C. 504, 508, 492 S.E.2d 816, 818 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  However, our courts have held that an investigating police officer may give opinion testimony if he is qualified as an expert.Â  Goode, 305 S.C. at 177, 406 S.E.2d at 392-93; see also State v. Kelly, 285 S.C. 373, 374, 329 S.E.2d 442, 443 (1985) (â€œA police officer may not give his opinions as to the cause of the accident.Â  He may only testify regarding his direct observations unless he is qualified as an expert.â€) (emphasis added).Â  
Here, the trial court permitted Abramson to testify as an expert after assessing his qualifications, and we can discern no error in the trial courtâ€™s qualification of Abramson on the issue of speed. Â Abramson testified he had 16 years experience as a highway patrolman; received training at the South Carolina Criminal Justice Academy; received instruction in advanced accident investigation at an institute in Florida, including training in estimating speed based on skid marks; and involvement in investigating hundreds of cases.Â  In light of Abramsonâ€™s training and experience, we find he could have provided assistance to the jury on the question of speed.Â  Moreover, any defect in the amount and quality of education and experience goes to the weight of the expertâ€™s testimony and not to its admissibility.Â  Lee v. Suess, 318 S.C. 283, 286, 457 S.E.2d 344, 346 (1995). 
Even if the trial court judge had abused his discretion by qualifying Abramson as an expert and allowing him to testify on the issue of speed, Appellants cannot show they were prejudiced as a result.Â  Abramsonâ€™s testimony was cumulative to several other witnessesâ€™ trial testimony, including that of the Appellantsâ€™ own expert, Jur.Â  See Gulledge, 328 S.C. at 509, 492 S.E.2d at 818 (holding cumulative testimony was an insufficient ground for reversal even though the trial court erred in permitting a non-expert patrolman to testify).Â  Abramson testified Preston was traveling â€œat least 45 mph.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  Preston himself admitted he was speeding, Champion estimated the motorcycleâ€™s speed at between 45 and 50 mph, and Spalviero testified that Preston was â€œflying.â€Â  Appellantsâ€™ expert, Jur, estimated the motorcycle was traveling at 53 to 61 mph, and he agreed that 45 mph was Prestonâ€™s minimum speed based on the length of the skid mark.Â  Therefore, Abramsonâ€™s testimony was cumulative.Â  Accordingly, the order of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED. Â Â Â Â Â  
 GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: Willis v. Grand Strand Sandwich Shop
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Donald R. Willis, Respondent,
v.
Grand Strand Sandwich Shop and N.C. Insurance Guaranty Assn,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-590
Submitted September 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 18, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
Jason W. Lockhart, McAngus, Goudelock, & Courie, of Columbia, for Appellants
Eric C. Davis, Atwater & Davis, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation case, the North Carolina Guaranty Association (N.C. Guaranty) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order reversing the Appellate Panel of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Full Commission) and reinstating the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings.Â  The Full Commission held N.C. Guaranty was not bound by the Single Commissionerâ€™s order, which was issued during a stay mandated by the South Carolina Property and Casualty Insurance Guaranty Association Act.Â  We reverse.Â Â  
FACTS
On March 19, 2001, Willis filed a form 50 seeking benefits for a back injury sustained in the scope and course of his employment and requesting a hearing on the matter.Â  At the time of Willisâ€™s hearing request, Reliance National Indemnity Company (Reliance) was the insurance carrier.Â  Although the Single Commissioner timely notified Reliance that a hearing was scheduled for September 4, 2001, Reliance failed to respond by filing a form 51 or by appearing at the hearing.Â  Therefore, the Single Commissioner admitted Willisâ€™s Administrative Procedures Act submissions and heard Willisâ€™s testimony in Relianceâ€™s absence.Â  
On October 2, 2001, the State of Pennsylvania issued an order declaring Reliance insolvent.Â  At that time, all claims were turned over to the South Carolina Property and Casualty Insurance Guaranty Association (S.C. Guaranty) for handling.Â  On November 6, 2001, the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission notified Willisâ€™s attorney that section 38-31-160 of the South Carolina Code (2002) mandated a 90-day stay for all suits and proceedings involving Reliance due to its insolvency.Â  
The Single Commissioner issued an order on November 19, 2001 and made the following findings of fact: Willis sustained a back injury in the course and scope of his employment on April 9, 1999, Reliance was responsible for payment of medical care and temporary total disability benefits from April 12, 1999 until September 6, 1999, and Willis sustained 51% permanent disability.Â  
Thereafter, Willisâ€™s attorney forwarded a copy of the Single Commissionerâ€™s order to S.C. Guaranty and requested payment.Â  On March 14, 2002 Willis sent a letter to S.C. Guaranty indicating he was informed that because Willis was a North Carolina resident, his claim would be referred to N.C. Guaranty and requesting contact information for N.C. Guaranty.Â  S.C. forwarded Willisâ€™s letter to N.C. Guaranty.Â  N.C. Guaranty contacted Willisâ€™s attorney to obtain information after it received notice of the claim on March 22, 2002. Â Willisâ€™s attorney sent a copy of Willisâ€™s file on April 17, 2002 and a copy of the complete workersâ€™ compensation package on May 7, 2002.Â  
On August 30, 2002, N.C. Guaranty filed a motion to reconsider or vacate the Single Commissionerâ€™s order, arguing it could not be legally bound by the Single Commissionerâ€™s decision.Â  By order dated September 20, 2002, the Single Commissioner denied the motion.Â  N.C. Guaranty requested review by the Full Commission.Â  By an order dated March 21, 2003, the Full Commission set aside the Single Commissionerâ€™s order and substituted its findings of fact.Â  The Full Commission found Willis was entitled to payment of 21 weeks of temporary total disability benefits and all related medical bills, but that the matter would be remanded to a jurisdictional commissioner for a hearing on the extent of Willisâ€™s permanent partial disability.Â  
Thereafter, Willis appealed to the circuit court, which reversed the order of the Full Commission and reinstated the Single Commissionerâ€™s order.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 288, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Pursuant to the APA, this courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
N.C. Guaranty argues the circuit court erred in reversing the Full Commissionâ€™s decision, which vacated the Single Commissionerâ€™s order and remanded Willisâ€™ partial permanent disability claim to permit N.C. Guaranty to defend on the merits.Â  N.C. Guaranty contends the Single Commissioner exceeded his authority by issuing a final ruling during the mandated 90 day stay period and that the Full Commission correctly set aside that order.Â  We agree.[1]Â  
The South Carolina Property and Casualty Insurance Guaranty Association Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-31-1 to 93, provides protection for insureds in the event their insurance carriers become insolvent by providing payment for covered claims.Â  S.C. Prop. and Cas. Ins. Guar. Assâ€™n v. Carolinaâ€™s Roofing and Sheet Metal Contractorâ€™s Self-Insurers Fund, 303 S.C. 368, 369, 401 S.E.2d 144, 145 (1991).Â  Section 38-31-160 of the Act provides a mandatory automatic 90-day stay for all claims against an insolvent insurer: â€œAll proceedings involving covered claims in which the insolvent insurer is a party or is obligated to defend a party in any court in this State must be stayed ninety days from the date insolvency is determined to permit proper defense by the association.â€Â Â  
In the case sub judice, the Single Commissioner held a hearing on September 4, 2001, but didnâ€™t issue a final, written order until November 19, 2001.Â  The Single Commissioner clearly issued his decision after the mandatory 90-day stay went into effect on October 2, 2001, the date Reliance was declared insolvent.Â  First Union Natâ€™l Bank of S.C. v. Hitman, Inc., 306 S.C. 327, 329, 411 S.E.2d 681, 682 (Ct. App. 1991) (holding an order is not final until it is written and entered); see also Rule 58(a), SCRCP (judgment not effective until entered in the record).Â  Because the Single Commissioner was without authority to issue a final written order during the mandatory stay period, the order dated November 19, 2001 was void ab initio.Â  See Turner v. Malone, 24 S.C. 398 (1886) (holding a judgment or order entered without jurisdiction is void ab initio); see also Webster v. Clanton, 259 S.C. 387, 391, 192 S.E.2d 214, 216 (1972) (explaining that an order issued without jurisdiction is void and a void order has no legal effect); cf Ex parte Reichlyn, 310 S.C. 495, 499, 427 S.E.2d 661, 663 (1993) (holding judgment entered in violation of the automatic stay in a bankruptcy proceeding is void because the court lacks subject matter jurisdiction to take any action inconsistent with the stay).Â  Therefore, the Full Commission properly decided N.C. Guaranty could not be legally bound by the November 19, 2001 order.
N.C. Guaranty also argues the trial court erred in reinstating the Single Commissionerâ€™s order.Â  N.C. Guaranty contends the Full Commissionâ€™s findings of fact are supported by substantial evidence and should be affirmed.Â  We agree.Â  
The Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder in workersâ€™ compensation cases and is not bound by the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 517, 526 S.E.2d 725, 729. Â â€œA reviewing court should affirm a decision by the Full Commission unless it is clearly erroneous in view of the substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 183, 528 S.E.2d 435, 440 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
Having decided the Single Commissionerâ€™s order dated November 19, 2001 was void ab initio, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s order reinstating the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings.Â  Because the Full Commission is the ultimate finder of fact in a workersâ€™ compensation case and its order was not issued during the automatic stay period, we uphold the order dated March 21, 2003.Â  N.C. Guaranty is not seeking to escape liability for the claim.Â  The Full Commission ordered N.C. Guaranty to pay Willis 21 weeks of temporary total disability benefits and all related medical bills. Moreover, the Full Commission simply remanded the issue of permanent partial disability to allow N.C. Guaranty the opportunity to defend the claim on the merits because the Single Commissionerâ€™s order was improperly issued.Â  Therefore, the order of the circuit court is 
REVERSED.Â  
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur. 

[1]Â  Because we find the Single Commissionerâ€™s order was void ab initio, we need not address the circuit courtâ€™s finding that N.C. Guaranty was not authorized by section 38-31-160 of the South Carolina Code (2002) to apply to have the judgment set aside.
