title: Chase Manhattan Bank v. Bailey
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The Chase Manhattan Bank, successor by merger to Chase Bank of Texas
N.A. f/k/a Texas Commerce Bank N.A., as Custodian, Respondent,
v.
Renee C. Bailey, Commercial Credit Corporation, S.C. Electric and Gas Co., and Inga Sander,
Defendants,
of whom Renee C. Bailey is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Patrick R. Watts, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-591
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 21, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
A. Christopher Potts, of Charleston, for Appellant.
John J. Hearn, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Renee C. Bailey appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of her motion to set aside or otherwise grant her relief from a judgment of foreclosure.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In January 2001, Chase Manhattan Bank sued Bailey seeking to foreclose on her home in Summerville, South Carolina.Â  Bailey failed to answer the complaint, and Chase filed an affidavit of default and, in the latter part of April, was granted a default judgment of foreclosure and sale.Â  In May, Bailey filed a Chapter 13 bankruptcy petition.Â  Further activity on the foreclosure action was suspended by the automatic stay imposed by the bankruptcy law.Â  
As a part of her restructuring plan in bankruptcy, Bailey was to continue making regular monthly mortgage payments directly to Chase and, in addition, a smaller payment to the bankruptcy court to apply to arrearages owed Chase.Â  After failing to make the requisite normal monthly payments, Bailey reached an agreement with Chase in December 2001, which was memorialized in a consent order.Â  The court-ordered agreement provided that the automatic stay would be reinstated as it applied to the home, and Bailey would be allowed to continue possession of the property on the condition that she pay Chase $6,246.80 in arrearages and continue making regular monthly mortgage payments.Â  The order further provided that upon failure by Bailey to comply with these conditions, Chase would be allowed to submit an affidavit to that effect, together with a proposed order, and the automatic stay would be terminated without further notice or hearing.Â  
According to the record, Bailey paid the arrearages and made a monthly mortgage payment in January 2002.Â  Bailey submitted a payment to Chaseâ€™s loan servicer in February, but that payment was rejected.[2]Â  Bailey corresponded with the loan servicer explaining that the loan had been reinstated pursuant to the consent order.Â  Bailey then made a partial payment in March that was rejected, and a payment in April that was rejected due to non-sufficient funds.Â  Bailey continued to communicate intermittently with the loan servicer over the following months, but made no additional payments.Â  Chase filed an affidavit of default with the bankruptcy court.Â  Bailey did not contest the affidavit.[3]Â  
Bailey then filed a pleading captioned â€œSupplemental Answer and Counterclaimsâ€ with the circuit court in response to the original foreclosure action in an effort to prevent the public sale.Â  The trial court granted Chaseâ€™s motion to dismiss the Answer and Counterclaims.Â  In February 2004, nearly three years after the commencement of the initial foreclosure action, Bailey filed a motion to set aside the default or for other relief from judgment, relying on the procedure allowed by Rule 55(c), SCRCP and Rule 60, SCRCP.Â  (R. 9).Â  The trial court denied the motion.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A motion to vacate or set aside a default judgment is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Tri-County Ice & Fuel Co. v. Palmetto Ice Co., 303 S.C. 237, 242, 399 S.E.2d 779, 782 (1990).Â  An abuse of discretion arises when the decision of the trial court is controlled by an error of law or where its order is based on factual conclusions that are without evidentiary support.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Bailey claims the trial court erred in failing to set aside the judgment of foreclosure because events occurring after final judgment was rendered make enforcement of the judgment inequitable.Â  We disagree.
Rule 60(b)(5), SCRCP, in pertinent part, includes the following provision:

(b) Mistakes; Inadvertence; Excusable Neglect; Newly Discovered Evidence; Fraud, etc.Â  On motion and upon such terms as are just, the court may relieve a party or his legal representative from final judgment, order, or proceeding for the following reasons:
(5) the judgment has been satisfied, released, or discharged, or a prior judgment upon which it is based has been reversed or otherwise vacated, or it is no longer equitable that the judgment should have prospective application.
The motion shall be made within a reasonable time . . . .

First, we are not convinced that Baileyâ€™s motion was filed within a reasonable time.Â  Chase correctly points out that the motion was filed almost three years after entry of the default judgment.Â  For much of that time the foreclosure action was stayed.Â  However, when the stay was lifted, instead of filing a motion to set aside default, Bailey filed what purported to be responsive pleadings as if no default existed.Â  No initial answer had ever been filed in the foreclosure action, making the filing of normal responsive pleadings inappropriate.Â  Then, six months later, the motion to set aside default was filed, alleging the same facts set forth in the supplemental answer and counterclaims.Â  During this period Bailey continued to have possession of the home.
Assuming arguendo that Baileyâ€™s motion was not untimely, her arguments regarding Chaseâ€™s â€œinequitableâ€ conduct are unpersuasive.Â  When considering whether to grant relief from final judgments, â€œa court must balance the interest of finality against the need to provide a fair and just resolution of the dispute.â€Â  Chewning v. Ford Motor Co., 354 S.C. 72, 79-80, 579 S.E.2d 605, 609 (2003).Â  The supreme court in Chewning recognized the longstanding policy toward final judgments and that â€œimportant benefits are achieved by the preservation of final judgments.â€Â  Id. at 86, 579 S.E.2d at 613.Â  Consequently, the scale is generally tipped in favor of denying relief from a final judgment absent a compelling reason.Â  
In this case, there is no evidence Chase acted in a manner that would render enforcement of the judgment inequitable under Rule 60(b)(5).Â  It is undisputed that Bailey defaulted on her mortgage payments prior to the foreclosure action and that she did not make the payments to Chase under the bankruptcy courtâ€™s initial plan.Â  Bailey contends, however, that once the December 2001 payment agreement was made she â€œstrictly complied with the consent order.â€Â  That contention is not supported by the evidence.Â  The record shows that a March payment was made, but it was only a partial payment.Â  The record further shows that the April payment was rejected due to non-sufficient funds.Â  No further payments were remitted by Bailey.Â  
According to affidavits of Baileyâ€™s husband and her attorney, a Chase representative, Bobby McGrath, advised Bailey in or about March or April that Bailey could â€œtack any returned or missed payments to the back end of the mortgage.â€Â  In August 2002, a mortgage company representative advised Bailey that she should pay all arrearages immediately or the foreclosure would proceed.Â  Bailey contends that the continuation of this action is inequitable in light of the representation that she could tack the missed payments on the back end of the loan.Â  However, Bailey neglects to consider that between the time of the conversation with McGrath and the communication in August, she still neglected to make any payments to Chase.
Finally, it appears that Chaseâ€™s attorney proposed a conditional loan modification to Bailey a few days prior to a motion hearing in the case.Â  The proposal was open for acceptance until the morning of October 14, 2003.Â  Baileyâ€™s attorney testified by affidavit that he left a message with Chaseâ€™s attorney accepting the offer on the morning of October 14.Â  However, there is nothing in the record to indicate Chase received notice of this last-minute acceptance.Â  Consequently, we cannot conclude it was inequitable for Chase to proceed with a motion hearing scheduled for the following day. 
Based on the evidence before us, we find no abuse of discretion on the part of the trial court.Â  Accordingly, the ruling of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
 STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  It appears Baileyâ€™s loan was assigned to a different loan servicing company during this period of time.Â  
[3] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Baileyâ€™s bankruptcy action was subsequently dismissed.

title: Cooper v. Dick Smith Motors
text:
Screening Report / Proposed Opinion


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Lonnie Cooper, Respondent,
v.
Dick Smith Motors, Employer, and S.C. Automobile Dealers Assoc./Randolph Hope Co., Carrier,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-593
Submitted October 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 21, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
Louise Elaine Mozingo, of Camden, for Appellants.
Thomas K. Fowler, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Dick Smith Motors and its insurance carrier, S.C. Automobile Dealers Association (collectively â€œAppellantsâ€), appeal a circuit court order reversing a decision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission which held that Lonnie Cooper did not aggravate a pre-existing back problem as a result of an admitted injury to his knee and therefore, that he reached maximum medical improvement for his injuries.Â  We reverse.Â  
FACTS
Lonnie Cooper sustained an admitted injury to his left knee on July 22, 2002 while working as a service technician/mechanic for Dick Smith Motors.Â  The injury occurred when Cooper slipped getting into a vehicle.Â  Cooper first received medical services for the injury at Doctorâ€™s Care, where he complained of ankle and knee pain.Â  He was referred to Dr. Bethea, who served as his treating physician.
On March 20, 2003, after approximately 17 visits to Dr. Bethea, and two knee surgeries, Dr. Bethea declared Cooper reached maximum medical improvement for his knee injuries.Â  At that time he stated that Cooper suffered a 25 percent permanent physical impairment of the injured extremity.Â  
On June 5, 2003, Appellants filed a Form 21 seeking to stop compensation for the knee injury and requesting credit for overpayment of temporary benefits.Â  Although Cooper was pro se at this point, he obtained the services of an attorney who filed a pre-hearing brief asserting that Cooper injured his knee and would be seeking all benefits applicable.Â  On July 18, 2003, the attorney also filed a Form 50 requesting further medical treatment for the knee injury and a finding of general disability.Â  
A hearing on Appellantsâ€™ Form 21 was held before a single workersâ€™ compensation commissioner on July 31, 2003.Â  During the pre-trial conference Cooper sought to leave the record open in order to submit the deposition of Dr. Bethea to support his claim that he also injured his back in the accident.Â  The commissioner left the record open for 30 days and on August 28, 2003, the commissioner received Dr. Betheaâ€™s deposition and a report by Dr. Poletti.Â  Appellants objected to admission of Dr. Polettiâ€™s report and the commissioner sustained the objection, leaving the report in the commissionâ€™s file as a proffer, but not considering it in rendering a decision.
During the hearing, Cooper testified that although the immediate problem after the accident was his left knee, he also began to experience numbness in his right leg and back pain.Â  Cooper stated that he mentioned the back problems several times to Dr. Bethea, but that the doctor repeatedly told him he needed to take care of one problem at a time.Â  He further testified that he did not receive any treatment for his back or right leg until he returned to Dr. Bethea using his health insurance.Â  
On cross-examination, opposing counsel confronted Cooper by bringing it to his attention that none of the records of Cooperâ€™s 17 visits to Dr. Bethea showed any mention of problems with his back or right leg.Â  Cooper responded that he told the doctor of the back pain after five or six visits and was aware that Dr. Bethea did not write anything in his reports concerning the back injury.Â  Also brought out on cross examination was the fact that Cooperâ€™s wife knew Dr. Bethea through her employment with a local hospital.Â  
In his deposition, Dr. Bethea testified to the injuries Cooper sustained to his knee and the course of treatment that was followed.Â  Dr. Bethea also testified that treatment was not rendered for Cooperâ€™s back problems until three months after the doctor declared Cooper reached maximum medical improvement for his knee injury.Â  He mentioned, however, that although he did not have any record of treatment for the back prior to that date, he thought Cooper did mention it in previous visits.Â  Dr. Bethea further testified that a twisting-type injury â€œcould be consistent with an aggravation . . . of pre-existing back problems,â€ although he could not say that with any degree of certainty.Â  
On November 26, 2003, the single commissioner issued an order finding inter alia, that Cooper reached maximum medical improvement for the admitted knee injury on March 20, 2003, the day he was released by Dr. Bethea.Â  The commissioner further found that â€œthe greater weight of evidence [did] not support a finding that [Cooper] sustained a compensable injury to the back as a result of the left knee injury on July 22, 2002.â€Â  Based on the evidence, the commissioner found Cooper was entitled to 78 weeks of compensation based on a 40 percent permanent partial disability to the injured leg minus credit for temporary total disability paid by Appellants since June 3, 2003.Â  
Cooper appealed this decision to the Full Commission and review took place on June 29, 2004.Â  The next day, the Full Commission issued an order affirming the commissionerâ€™s order in its entirety.Â  Â Â Cooper appealed the Full Commissionâ€™s decision to the circuit court and on September 30, 2004, the court issued an order reversing the Full Commission and remanding the matter back for a determination of the amount of benefits due Cooper.Â  
Specifically, the court held that â€œthe substantial evidence of the recordâ€ did not support the Full Commissionâ€™s decision.Â  The courtâ€™s decision was greatly influenced by the Dr. Bethea and Cooperâ€™s testimony that although the back injuries were not included in any written records, they were mentioned verbally while treatment for the knee was taking place.Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellantsâ€™ primary argument on appeal is that the circuit court erred in reversing the Full Commissionâ€™s finding that Cooper did not sustain an injury to his back as a result of the accident for which he received medical care.Â  Appellants argue this is especially true considering that the Commissionâ€™s decision was supported by substantial evidence.Â  We agree.
The Administrative Procedures Act applies to appeals from decisions of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  In an appeal from the Commission, neither this Court nor the circuit court may substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 617, 571 S.E.2d 92, 95 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œAny review of the Commissionâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.â€Â  Lockridge v. Santens of Am., Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Accordingly, we limit review to deciding whether the Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Corbin, 351 S.C. at 617, 571 S.E.2d at 95.Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence that, in viewing the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the same conclusion that the full commission reached.â€Â  Lockridge, 344 S.C. at 515, 544 S.E.2d at 844.Â  â€œThe â€˜possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€™â€Â  Lee v. Harborside CafÃ©, 350 S.C. 74, 78, 564 S.E.2d 354, 356 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984)).
Significantly, â€œ[t]he Appellate Panel is the ultimate fact finder in Workersâ€™ Compensation cases and is not bound by the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.â€Â  Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 517, 526 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Accordingly, the appellate panel has the final determination of witness credibility and also determines the weight to be accorded evidence.Â  Id.Â 
In the current case, after â€œcareful review,â€ the Commission found â€œthat [t]he findings of fact and conclusions of law as established by the hearing commissioner [were] correct.â€Â  (emphasis in original).Â  As such, the Commission adopted the hearing commissionerâ€™s findings of fact and rulings of law by reference into its final order as it is entitled to do under sections 42-17-40 and 1-23-350 of the South Carolina Code.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 42-17-40 (1976) & 1-23-350 (1986); see also Eaddy v. Smurfit-Stone Container Corp., 355 S.C. 154, 167-168, 584 S.E.2d 390, 397-398 (Ct. App. 2003) (interpreting these statutory provisions and concluding the Commission meets the requirements contained therein when it incorporates a single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact and rulings of law by reference into its order).
Considering the current case with these standards in mind, we find the record contains substantial evidence to support the commissionâ€™s decision.Â  It is undisputed that none of the records stemming from Cooperâ€™s medical care prior to his release for the knee injury mention any purported back problems.Â  In fact, as the single commissioner noted in the first order, there was no mention of a back injury on Cooperâ€™s original Form 50, nor was there mention of the injury in Cooperâ€™s pre-hearing brief.Â  It was not until a pre-trial conference on the Form 21 â€œstop paymentâ€ hearing that the back injury was mentioned at all.Â  Despite this fact, the commissioner allowed the record to be kept open for Dr. Betheaâ€™s deposition.
As noted previously, Dr. Bethea testified that no treatment was provided for Cooperâ€™s back injuries until three months after Cooper reached maximum medical improvement for his knee injury.Â  He also stated, however, that although there was no written record of Cooper complaining of back pain, he thought he recalled it being mentioned.Â  Dr. Bethea further opined that the original accident could have aggravated a pre-existing back problem.
To the extent Dr. Betheaâ€™s testimony can be read to support Cooperâ€™s claim that he mentioned the back injury before treatment for his knee was completed, the commissioner was in a better position to determine his credibility.Â  When it comes to expert medical testimony, its admission is designed to provide assistance to the Commission in coming to a correct conclusion; as such, the Commission is left with discretion to determine the weight and credit to be given to the testimony.Â  Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr. of Sumter, 334 S.C. 333, 340, 513 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1999).Â  Although expert medical testimony is entitled to great respect, the Commission as fact finder may disregard the testimony if there is other competent evidence in the record.Â  Id.Â  Accordingly, once expert testimony is admitted, the Commission may consider it in the same manner as it would any other testimony.Â  Id.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
As there is evidence in the record to support the finding that Cooper did not sustain a compensable injury to his back as a result of the admitted accident, we reverse the circuit court and reinstate the Full Commissionâ€™s decision.Â  Because we reverse on Appellantâ€™s primary issue, we decline to address Appellantsâ€™ remaining issues.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling appellate court need not review remaining issues when disposition of prior issues are dispositive). 
REVERSED. [1]
ANDERSON, J., HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Carolina First Bank v. Ashley Tower
text:
Prehearing Report / Proposed Opinion


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Carolina First Bank, Respondent,
v.
Ashley Tower, LP, Pendleton Partners, LLC and James B. Miller, Defendants,
of whom Pendleton Partners, LLC is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â JosephÂ  M. Strickland, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-594
Submitted October 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 21, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Allan R. Holmes, of Charleston, for Appellant.
John T. Moore and Jennifer West, and Louis H. Lang, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this mortgage foreclosure action, Pendleton Partners, LLC, appeals a master in equityâ€™s decision denying its request to set aside an entry of default.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Carolina First Bank (hereinafter â€œRespondentâ€) commenced this action by filing a complaint seeking foreclosure and appointment of a receiver against Ashley Tower, LP, Pendleton Partners, LLC, and James B. Miller.Â Â Â  
On December 21, 1998, James B. Miller and George T. Williams filed articles of organization with the Secretary of State creating Pendleton Partners, LLC.Â  Miller is listed as the initial agent for service of process.Â  According to the articles, the purpose of the limited liability company is the â€œownership, development and operation of real estate located at Pendleton and Pulaski Streetsâ€ in Columbia.Â  Williams and Miller are the sole members of the LLC and it is a member-managed limited liability company.Â  
On December 21, 2000, Ashley Tower, LP, executed a promissory note to Respondent in the principal amount of $350,000.[1]Â  To secure this note, Miller also mortgaged to Respondent all of the property owned at that time by Pendleton Partners, LLC.[2]Â  Â Subsequently, the mortgage went into default, and on August 23, 2002, Respondent filed its summons and complaint seeking foreclosure on the real property owned by Pendleton Partners, LLC.Â  
As all of the defendants failed to answer, Carolina First filed an affidavit of default on January 31, 2004.Â  The matter was referred the same day to the master in equity for Richland County.Â  On February 6, 2003, Pendleton Partners, LLC, (hereinafter â€œAppellantâ€) submitted a motion to set aside the default.Â  The motion was supported by an affidavit from Williams which, inter alia, alleged that Miller improperly mortgaged the property without Williamsâ€™ approval. 
After a hearing and upon review of the briefs submitted by both sides, the master-in-equity denied the motion by order dated September 25, 2003.Â  Appellant thereafter filed a notice of appeal to this Court, and on November 18, 2003, we issued a dismissal stating that an order refusing to grant relief from the entry of a default is not immediately appealable until after final judgment.Â  Upon receipt of this order, Appellant filed a petition for rehearing seeking a review of the dismissal.Â  On March 17, 2004, this court issued a second order affirming its determination that a default judgment is not immediately
appealable.  
Appellant then filed a petition for certiorari to the supreme court seeking review of this courtâ€™s decision.Â  On November 16, 2004, at Appellantâ€™s request, the supreme court dismissed the action.Â  After this dismissal, a foreclosure hearing was scheduled before the master-in-equity on December 15, 2004.Â  On December 3, 2004, George T. Williams submitted a motion to intervene in the foreclosure action.Â  Williams asserted several problems existed with the mortgage including a lack of consideration to Appellant or Williams and failure by Respondent to â€œexercise due diligence to ascertain the legal status of the LLC before the mortgage was executed.â€Â  
The master entertained the motion to intervene along with the foreclosure action on December 15, 2004.Â  In two separate orders, the master denied the motion to intervene and granted the foreclosure sought by Carolina First.Â Â Â  
LAW / ANALYSIS
Appellant now raises several alleged errors in the masterâ€™s rulings all relating to its failure to grant Appellantâ€™s motion to set aside the entry of default.
After a review of the record, however, it is not clear that any of Appellantâ€™s current arguments were actually raised to and ruled upon by the master.Â  The masterâ€™s orders do not contain any discussion of the merits and merely deny Appellantâ€™s motions.Â  There are no transcripts in the record of any hearing before the master as to the various motions, nor did appellant make any motions pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP seeking to clarify the masterâ€™s orders.
Accordingly, there is no way for this court to determine if the issues asserted on appeal have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.Â  As such, we find none of the issues are preserved for our review.Â Â Â  Â Â See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (finding an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appeal).
AFFIRMED.  [3]
ANDERSON, J., HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Miller signed the promissory note as general partner of Ashley Tower, LP.Â  
[2] The mortgage was signed by Miller as a â€œmanaging memberâ€ of Pendleton Partners, LLC.Â  
[3] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Linda Lee Henderson Powell, Respondent,
v.
James Kevin Powell, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From McCormick County
Â C. David Sawyer, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-595
Heard September 13, 2005 â€“ Filed November 21, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, MODIFIED IN PART,
VACATED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
AND REMANDED IN PART 


  
    
      
Thomas M. Neal, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Timothy E. Madden, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this consolidated appeal, Kevin Powell (Husband) appeals the family court order awarding Linda Powell (Wife):Â  a divorce based on Husbandâ€™s adultery; $4,000 per month in alimony; health insurance maintained by Husband; a life insurance policy maintained by Husband as security for alimony; sixty-eight percent of the marital estate, net of liabilities; and attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  Husband also appeals the family courtâ€™s decision in a separate action to deny his request to modify his alimony obligation.Â  Finally, Husband appeals the courtâ€™s order finding him in contempt for failing to pay alimony.Â  We affirm in part, modify in part, reverse in part, vacate in part, and remand. 
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married in 1989.Â  At the time of the marriage, Husband had a college degree and was employed by American Express as a financial advisor.Â  Wife had a high school diploma and owned a court reporting business.Â  During the marriage, Wife was diagnosed with breast cancer and underwent reconstructive surgery.Â  Wifeâ€™s reconstructive surgery led to complications necessitating several back surgeries.Â  Wife filed a claim under her long-term disability insurance and closed her court reporting business.Â Â

An appellate court may reverse a trial courtâ€™s decision regarding contempt only if it is without evidentiary support or it finds the trial court abused its discretion.Â 
Durlach v. Durlach, 359 S.C. 64, 70, 596 S.E.2d 908, 912 (2004).Â  â€œWillful disobedience of a court order may result in contempt.Â  A willful act is one done voluntarily and intentionally, with the specific intent of doing something the law forbids.â€Â  Id. at 71, 596 S.E.2d at 912 (citations omitted).Â  â€œBefore a court finds a person in contempt, the record must clearly and specifically reflect the contemptuous conduct.â€Â 
Brasington v. Shannon, 288 S.C. 183, 184, 341 S.E.2d 130, 131 (1986).Â  â€œIn a proceeding for contempt for violation of a court order, the moving party must show the existence of the order and the facts establishing the respondentâ€™s noncompliance.Â  The burden then shifts to the respondent to establish his defense and inability to comply with the order.â€Â  Id. (citations omitted).Â  Failure by an obligated spouse to make alimony payments required by court order constitutes a prima facie case for contempt.Â 
Dunson v. Dunson, 278 S.C. 210, 213, 294 S.E.2d 39, 40 (1982). Â 
At the contempt hearing, Husband acknowledged his awareness of the court order requiring him to pay Wife alimony.Â  In addition he admitted he had not paid alimony in over three months.Â  He simply maintained he did not have the funds to pay it.Â  However, Husband admitted he received approximately $20,000 to $25,000 during that same period of time.Â  In addition, he admitted taking several trips during the period he stopped paying alimony, including trips to Hawaii and California.Â  Thus, based on the evidence in the record, we find Husband failed to establish a defense of his inability to comply with the family courtâ€™s order, and the family court did not abuse its discretion in finding Husband in contempt. 
Although we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in holding Husband in contempt, we must vacate its order.Â  â€œGenerally, reversal of a judgment on appeal has the effect of vacating the judgment and leaving the case standing as if no such judgment had been rendered.Â  Consequently, a party who receives payment under a judgment subsequently reversed must restore whatever advantage he obtained thereby to his adversary.â€Â 
Brown v. Brown, 286 S.C. 56, 57, 331 S.E.2d 793, 793-94 (Ct. App. 1985) (citations omitted).Â  Therefore, given our decision to reverse the family courtâ€™s award of alimony under the divorce decree, Wife would not be entitled to receive the alimony Husband failed to pay under the contempt order.Â  Accordingly, we vacate the family courtâ€™s order finding Husband in contempt.
VI. Attorneyâ€™s Fees and Costs 
Husband argues the family court erred in requiring him to pay $30,000 of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and costs, in addition to $9,000 for Wifeâ€™s expert witness. Â Primarily, he asserts the discovery difficulties alluded to by the court did not exist.Â  In addition, Husband contends Wife incurred a majority of her attorneyâ€™s fees in preparation for trial after discovery and his failure to produce information relating to the Scientific Ag Industries stock was inadvertent.Â  
The family court has statutory authority to award attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(38) (Supp. 2004).Â  â€œAn award of attorneyâ€™s fees rests within the sound discretion of the trial judge and should not be disturbed on appeal unless there is an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).Â  In determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay, whether beneficial results were obtained by the attorney, the financial conditions of the parties, and the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fees on each party.Â  Griffith v. Griffith, 332 S.C. 630, 645, 506 S.E.2d 526, 534 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In determining what amount of attorneyâ€™s fees should be awarded, the court should consider â€œthe nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered; the time necessarily devoted to the case; the professional standing of counsel; the contingency of compensation; the beneficial results obtained; and the customary legal fees for similar services.â€Â  Id. at 645-46, 506 S.E.2d at 534.
The record indicates Wife incurred $28,972.99 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  These fees did not include Wifeâ€™s CPAâ€™s expert fee of $10,249.60 or the balance due to Wifeâ€™s appraiser of $350.Â  The family court ordered Husband to pay $30,000 to Wife in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs in addition to $9,000 towards Wifeâ€™s CPAâ€™s fees and $350 towards Wifeâ€™s appraiserâ€™s fees.Â Â  
In light of our decision to reverse the family courtâ€™s award of alimony to Wife, we find it appropriate to reconsider the family courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to Wife.Â  See 
Rogers v. Rogers, 343 S.C. 329, 334, 540 S.E.2d 840, 842 (2001) (â€œ[S]ince the beneficial result obtained by counsel is a factor in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees, when that result is reversed on appeal, the attorneyâ€™s fee award must also be reconsidered.â€).Â  Accordingly, we remand the matter to family court to reconsider the Wifeâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  Further, in light of our decision that alimony was inappropriate in this case, the family court should also consider on remand whether the alimony payments Husband made to Wife should be set-off against any award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  See Brown, 286 S.C. at 57, 331 S.E.2d at 793-94 (â€œ[A] party who receives payment under a judgment subsequently reversed must restore whatever advantage he obtained thereby to his adversary.â€).
VII.Â  Request of Modification 
Finally, Husband argues the family court erred in initially failing to assert jurisdiction over his request for modification of his alimony obligation and in denying his request to modify his alimony obligation.Â  Given our decision to reverse the family courtâ€™s decision to award Wife alimony we need not address these arguments.Â  
CONCLUSION
The family court erred in awarding Wife a divorce based on Husbandâ€™s adultery because Husband sufficiently established a defense of recrimination due to Wifeâ€™s adultery.Â  Thus, we reverse the family courtâ€™s decision to grant Wifeâ€™s divorce based on this ground.Â  However, we find the parties were entitled to a divorce based on one year of continuous separation.Â  Because we find Wife committed adultery, she is barred from receiving alimony.Â  Therefore, we reverse the family courtâ€™s award of alimony to Wife.Â  The family courtâ€™s valuation of Husbandâ€™s Rollover IRA was in error.Â  We find the correct value of this asset to be $12,353.11.Â  We find no error in the family courtâ€™s valuation of the other disputed marital assets, but we correct its allocation of the American Express stock in accordance with its valuation.Â  The family court did not abuse its discretion in apportioning the marital property.Â  In light of our determinations, we remand this matter to the family court to reconsider the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife and the appropriateness of a set-off of alimony paid.Â  Finally, based on our reversal of the family courtâ€™s award of alimony to Wife, we need not address Husbandâ€™s arguments concerning modification of Wifeâ€™s alimony award and we vacate the family courtâ€™s order finding Husband in contempt.Â  Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s orders are 
AFFIRMED IN PART, MODIFIED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, VACATED IN PART, and REMANDED IN PART.Â  
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2),
SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
T. D. Williams, IV, Respondent,
v.
South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-596
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 22, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
Frank L. Valenta, Jr., of Blythewood, for Appellant. 
William E. Durant, Jr., of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  T. D. Williams, IV was arrested for driving under the influence.Â  Williams failed to consent to a breath test offered by the arresting law enforcement officer.Â  As a result, the South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles (the Department) suspended Williamsâ€™ driverâ€™s license.Â  Williams challenged the suspension.Â  An administrative hearing was held, and the hearing officer affirmed the suspension.Â  The circuit court reversed. The Department appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision.Â  We reverse.[1]
FACTS
On June 14, 2003, South Carolina Highway Patrol Trooper S. S. McKenzie arrested Williams in Sumter County for driving under the influence.Â  Trooper McKenzie transported Williams to a breath test location for a breath test pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Section 56-5-2950 (Supp. 2004).Â  At the breath test facility, he advised Williams of his implied consent rights, orally and in writing, pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Section 56-5-2951 (Supp. 2004).Â  Upon reading the implied consent rights from the prescribed form, Trooper McKenzie requested that Williams sign a document acknowledging that he received a copy of the advisement form.Â  Williams declined to sign the document.Â  
Trooper McKenzie prepared the breath test machine according to State Law Enforcement Division (SLED) procedures and waited the standard twenty minutes.Â  During that time, Williams asked numerous questions of Trooper McKenzie, but Trooper McKenzie limited his responses to the information in the SLED advisement form.Â  
When the twenty-minute observation period elapsed and the breath test machine indicated it was time to take the test, Trooper McKenzie requested that Williams take the test.Â  Williams declined the breath test on the basis that his questions had not been answered to his satisfaction.Â  Based on Williamsâ€™ refusal, Trooper McKenzie issued Williams a Notice of Suspension.Â  
The Department suspended Williamsâ€™ driverâ€™s license for ninety days, as required by S.C. Code Ann. Section 56-5-2951 (Supp. 2004).Â  Williams requested an administrative hearing to challenge his suspension.Â  The Department held a hearing on August 20, 2003.Â  
At the administrative hearing, Trooper McKenzie maintained that Williams refused to submit to the breath test.Â  
Williams testified that when Trooper McKenzie indicated the breathalyzer machine was ready to receive a sample, he responded that he was not fully advised of his rights.Â  When questioned further about his decision to refuse the breath test, Williams stated, â€œI elected to continue trying to fully understand my rights.â€Â  Williams explained, â€œI just simply â€¦ my questions werenâ€™t being answered.â€Â  Â Â Â 
The hearing officer sustained the suspension.Â  In his report, the hearing officer made the following findings of fact:

6. The officer began the 20 minute observation period.Â  When the 20 minutes expired, he asked Mr. Williams if he wanted to submit to a breath test and he responded â€œNo.â€
7.Â  The officer concluded that Mr. Williams refused to submit to a breath test.

Williams appealed to the circuit court, arguing he never refused to submit to the breath test, and the hearing officer made findings of fact without factual support.Â  The circuit court judge initially upheld the suspension and held there was substantial evidence in the record that would permit reasonable minds to conclude Williams refused to submit to a breath test.Â  However, he later reversed the hearing officerâ€™s decision pursuant to a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion for reconsideration.Â  In his reversing order, the judge found the hearing officer based his decision to uphold Williamsâ€™ suspension on the erroneous finding that the breath test was expressly refused.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act, S.C. Code Ann. Sections 1-23-310 to 400 (2005), establishes the â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ rule as the standard for judicial review of a decision of an administrative agency.  S.C. Depâ€™t of Motor Vehicles v. Nelson, 364 S.C. 514, 518, 613 S.E.2d 544, 546 (Ct. App. 2005) (quoting Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306-07 (1981)).  The findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.  Kearse v. State Health & Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 318 S.C. 198, 200, 456 S.E.2d 892, 893 (1995).Â  â€œA court may not substitute its judgment for that of an agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact unless the agencyâ€™s findings are clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€  Summersell v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Public Safety, 334 S.C. 357, 363, 513 S.E.2d 619, 622 (Ct. App. 1999), vacated in part on other grounds, 337 S.C. 19, 522 S.E.2d 144 (1999).Â  Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.  Miller v. State Roofing Co., 312 S.C. 452, 454, 441 S.E.2d 323, 324-25 (1994).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Department argues that the circuit court judge erred in reversing Williamsâ€™ suspension.Â  We agree.
The circuit court judge concluded the hearing officer based his order upholding the suspension on the erroneous finding that the breath test was expressly refused.Â  Citing to Lloyd v. SCDHEC, 328 S.C. 419, 491 S.E.2d 592 (Ct. App. 1997), vacated, 332 S.C. 421, 504 S.E.2d 605 (Ct. App. 1998), for the proposition that the hearing officerâ€™s findings did not rationally support the conclusions reached, the judge reversed the hearing officerâ€™s decision.Â  
We believe the circuit court judge misapplied the applicable standard of review when he failed to consider the record as a whole.[2]Â  An appeal from action of an administrative agency must be sustained if supported by substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â Â  
It is undisputed that Williams did not expressly refuse the breath test by stating â€œnoâ€; however, S.C. Code Ann. Section 56-5-2951 (Supp. 2004) does not require an â€œexpressâ€ refusal.[3]Â  The record is replete with evidence showing Williams refused the breath test.Â  The arresting officer testified numerous times that Williams â€œelected not to provide a breath sampleâ€ and that Williams never made an attempt to take the test.Â  Williams acknowledged he was offered the breath test but declined to take it because he felt he was not fully advised of his rights.Â  Moreover, Williams never argued at the administrative hearing that he did not refuse the test; Williams acknowledged his refusal but claimed his refusal was somehow justified because his questions were not answered to his satisfaction and he did not fully understand his rights.Â  During his opening remarks at the administrative hearing, Williamsâ€™ attorney stated:

[W]e believe that â€¦ that the evidence will show that â€¦ that during the advisement of rights there was some indication or comments that were inconsistent with the form and it led to some confusion and therefore there was â€¦ no test was taken.Â  Thatâ€™s not the issue.Â  The issue is in our minds was the â€¦ were the â€¦ were the advisement of rights properly given and itâ€™s our position that it wasnâ€™t a refusal based on an understanding of the rights and an exercise of that right to refuse because of some inconsistencies in â€¦ in what happened that day.

The hearing officerâ€™s erroneous finding that Williams said â€œnoâ€ does not alter the inescapable fact that the record as a whole compellingly establishes Williamsâ€™ refusal.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the order of the circuit court and reinstate the suspension.
CONCLUSION
The order of the circuit court is hereby
REVERSED. 
STILWELL, KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  In his order, the circuit court judge states that he considered the substantial evidence on the record as a whole; however, he reversed based on the single factual finding that Williams did not expressly refuse the breath test.Â  
[3] Â Â Â Â Â Â  South Carolina Code Ann. Section 56-5-2951 (Supp. 2004) provides, in pertinent part, as follows:
The Department of Motor Vehicles must suspend the driverâ€™s license, permit, or nonresident operating privilege of or deny the issuance of a license or permit to a person who drives a motor vehicle and refuses to submit to a test provided for in Section 56-5-2950 . . . .

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The Pointes of Plantation Pointe Ownersâ€™ Association, Respondent,
v.
Donald L. Rockwell and Torrie N. Rockwell, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Newberry County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-597
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 22, 2005Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Karl S. Brehmer and J. Austin Hood, both of Columbia, for Appellants. 
John T. Lay, Jr. and Stephen D. Porter, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This case involves a lawsuit filed by a homeownersâ€™ association, The Pointes of Plantation Ownersâ€™ Association (the Association) against homeowners in the development, Donald and Torrie Rockwell.Â  The Rockwells appeal from the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment for the Association that dismissed certain of their counterclaims with prejudice.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of the Rockwellsâ€™ abuse of process claim.Â  The elements of an abuse of process claim are: (1) an ulterior purpose and (2) a â€œwillfulâ€ or overt act â€œin the use of the processâ€ that is improper because it is either unauthorized or aimed at an illegitimate collateral objective.Â  Food Lion, Inc. v. United Food & Commercial Workers Intâ€™l Union, 351 S.C. 65, 71, 567 S.E.2d 251, 253-54 (Ct. App. 2002). Â Importantly, an ulterior purpose or bad intention is insufficient to state a claim.Â  There must be proof that a collateral objective was the sole or paramount reason for acting.Â  â€œ[A] party who simply pursues a lawsuit with a collateral purpose in mind has done nothing improper.â€Â  Id. at 76, 567 S.E.2d at 256.Â  Here, the Associationâ€™s complaint alleges that the Rockwellsâ€™ home was not constructed according to the approved plans in certain respects.Â  The approved plans were those submitted by the Rockwells.Â  Thus, the Association simply sought an order requiring the Rockwells to comply with their own plans.Â  The Rockwellsâ€™ efforts to recast the lawsuit into something it is not finds no traction in this record.Â  Even assuming the Association pursued the action â€œwith a collateral purpose in mind,â€ there is no abuse of process.Â  This cause of action fails as a matter of law.Â  
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The circuit court properly granted summary judgment for the Association as to the Rockwellsâ€™ negligence counterclaim.Â  Unless a plaintiff can show a duty of care existed in a negligence action, the defendant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Huggins v. Citibank, N.A., 355 S.C. 329, 332, 585 S.E.2d 275, 276-77 (2003).Â  The Associationâ€™s only duty in this case arose by contract.Â  See Seabrook Island Prop. Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n v. Berger,
365 S.C. 234, ___, 616 S.E.2d 431, 434 (Ct. App. 2005) (quoting Seabrook Island Prop. Owners Assâ€™n v. Pelzer, 292 S.C. 343, 347, 356 S.E.2d 411, 414 (Ct. App. 1987)) (â€œRestrictive covenants are contractual in nature and bind the parties thereto in the same manner as any other contract.â€);
Tommy L. Griffin Plumbing & Heating Co. v. Jordan, Jones & Goulding, Inc., 320 S.C. 49, 54-55, 463 S.E.2d 85, 88 (1995) (holding that no tort liability arises from a breach of contract).Â  Thus, no duty existed unless there was a special relationship between the parties.Â  Id. at 55, 463 S.E.2d at 88.Â  The Rockwells have not cited any authority holding that a special relationship is created in this situation triggering a duty in tort.Â  This argument is accordingly deemed abandoned.Â  See Glasscock, Inc. v. U.S. Fidelity and Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œSouth Carolina law clearly states that short, conclusory statements made without supporting authority are deemed abandoned on appeal and therefore not presented for review.â€).Â  Therefore, the negligence counterclaim also fails as a matter of law.Â  
3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of the Rockwellsâ€™ outrage counterclaim. Â To state a claim for outrage, or intentional infliction of emotional distress, a plaintiff must show that: (1) the defendant intentionally or recklessly inflicted severe emotional distress, or was certain or substantially certain that such distress would result from his conduct; (2) the conduct was so extreme and outrageous as to exceed all possible bounds of decency and must be regarded as atrocious and utterly intolerable in a civilized community; (3) the actions of the defendant caused the plaintiffâ€™s emotional distress; and (4) the emotional distress suffered by the plaintiff was so severe that no reasonable person could be expected to endure it.Â  Bergstrom v. Palmetto Health Alliance, 358 S.C. 388, 401, 596 S.E.2d 42, 48 (2004); Talamantes v. Berkeley County Sch. Dist., 340 F. Supp. 2d 684, 691 (D.S.C. 2004).Â  The Associationâ€™s actions in this case clearly did not rise to the level of being actionable under this standard.Â  Accordingly, the trial judge correctly granted summary judgment for the Association on this counterclaim.Â  
AFFIRMED. 
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Judy Martin, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-598Â Â Â 
Heard November 8, 2005 â€“ Filed November 28, 2005 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Sr. Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia, Harold W. Gowdy, III, Seventh Circuit Solicitorâ€™s Office, of Spartanburg, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Judy Martin appeals her sentence for voluntary manslaughter in connection with the shooting death of her husband.Â  We affirm.
BACKGROUND
On February 25, 2002, the Spartanburg County Grand Jury indicted Martin for the murder of her husband. On July 28, 2003, Martin entered an Alford plea to voluntary manslaughter.Â  
After accepting Martinâ€™s plea, the trial judge acknowledged Martin was â€œraising a battered spouse defense to some extentâ€ and permitted both sides to present witnesses regarding this issue.Â  Of particular note during this hearing was the testimony of Jessie Scott Martin (Scottie), the adult son of both Martin and the victim and the only eyewitness to the incident other than Martin herself.Â  According to Scottie, the victim approached Martin while holding up a spoon in a threatening way.Â  As Martin attempted to retreat from the victim, he continued to move toward her until she backed into the living room wall.Â  Martin then pulled a pistol from her purse and started shooting.Â  Several shots misfired, but two bullets hit the victim.Â  Scottie testified Martin and the victim had always argued and fought.Â  Martin and other witnesses corroborated this statement.Â  The defense submitted pictures of Martin with bruises and other injuries.Â  The State, however, presented witnesses who asserted they knew of no abusive behavior by the victim.
At the conclusion of the hearing, the trial judge concluded Martin failed to present credible evidence that criminal domestic violence played any part in the offense.Â  Specifically, the trial judge found as follows:

I . . . do not find that there is credible evidence of criminal domestic violence involved in this situation.Â  I do believe that, at some point, there may [have] been [domestic violence] in these part[iesâ€™] history.Â  I donâ€™t believe that it played any part in what happened.
. . .
The defendant has the burden of establishing that by the preponderance of the evidence.Â  I respectfully decline to find that thereâ€™s credible evidence, based upon what was presented, that played any part at all in this offense.

Based on this reasoning, the trial judge sentenced Martin to twenty-two years imprisonment. 
In Martinâ€™s initial appeal, the South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense filed an Anders brief and petition to be relieved as counsel, setting forth as the sole issue of arguable merit the contention that the trial judge erred in finding the record contained insufficient credible evidence of criminal domestic violence.Â  On December 7, 2004, this court denied the petition to be relieved as counsel and directed the parties to brief the following issues:Â  (1) whether the trial judge, in determining Martinâ€™s eligibility for parole under South Carolina Code section 16-25-90, applied the correct burden of proof regarding Martinâ€™s presentation of credible evidence of a history of criminal domestic violence suffered at the hands of the victim,[1] and (2) whether the trial judge, in determining Martinâ€™s eligibility for parole under South Carolina code section 16-25-60, incorrectly required her to prove that the incident leading to the fatal shooting of the victim resulted from domestic violence.[2]Â  
DISCUSSION
1.Â  After reviewing the briefs and examining the record anew, we agree with the State that the issue of whether the trial judge applied the correct burden of proof in determining Martinâ€™s eligibility for parole under South Carolina Code section 16-25-90 cannot be addressed in this appeal.Â  During the hearing, Martin never mentioned section 16-25-90 or requested any rulings regarding her eligibility for parole.Â  Moreover, we have found nothing in the record suggesting the trial judge considered the history of domestic violence between Martin and her husband as anything other than a general mitigating circumstance to support her request for a lenient sentence.[3]Â  
2.Â  Likewise we do not address the issue of whether the trial judge, in determining Martinâ€™s eligibility for parole under South Carolina code section 16-25-60, incorrectly required her to prove the incident leading to the fatal shooting of the victim resulted from domestic violence.Â  Defense counsel never raised this issue to the trial judge.Â  In any event, we agree with the State that section 16-25-60 would not have been applicable to the present case.[4]
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  In 2002, South Carolina Code section 16-25-90 provided as follows:

Notwithstanding any provision of Chapters 13 and 21 of Title 24, and notwithstanding any other provision of law, an inmate who was convicted of, or pled guilty or nolo contendere to, an offense against a household member shall be eligible for parole after serving one-fourth of his prison term when the inmate at the time he pled guilty to, nolo contendere to, or was convicted of an offense against the household member, or in post- conviction proceedings pertaining to the plea or conviction, presented credible evidence of a history of criminal domestic violence, as provided in Section 16-25-20, suffered at the hands of the household member. This section shall not affect the provisions of Section 17-27-45.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-25-90 (1985).Â  The statute was amended in 2003; however, the changes do not appear to be of a nature that would have affected our disposition of this appeal.
[2]Â  South Carolina Code section 16-25-60 requires the court to consider the following in determining whether or not to suspend the imposition or execution of all or part of a sentence for criminal domestic violence:Â  (1) the nature and severity of the offense, the number of times the offender has repeated the offense, and the best interests and safety of the victim.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-25-60(D) (1985).Â  This section was omitted by 2003 Acts 92, Â§ 2, effective January 1, 2004.
[3]Â  See State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 693 (2003) (â€œIn order for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, it must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge.â€).
[4]Â  Section 16-25-60 applied only to the suspension of a sentence for a conviction of criminal domestic violence, as provided in section 16-25-20 or section 16-25-50.Â  Martinâ€™s conviction was not for a criminal domestic violence offense.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Michelle Tower, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        SC Department of Corrections, Employer, and State Accident Fund, Carrier, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-599
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 28, 2005 Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Katherine Carruth Link, of W. Columbia, Kenneth M. Mathews, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Amy Virginia Cofield-Derrick, of Lexington, Cynthia B. Polk, of Columbia, Thomas Carl Cofield, of Lexington, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation case, Michelle Tower appeals a circuit court order affirming the full commissionâ€™s denial of her claim for benefits.Â  Tower, an administrative assistant for the South Carolina Department of Corrections, sought benefits under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act for an injury she sustained on October 30, 2002, when she had an altercation with another employee.Â  The Department denied Towerâ€™s claim was compensable, asserting Towerâ€™s injuries resulted from horseplay that she had instigated.Â  At issue in this appeal is whether the circuit court erred in holding substantial evidence supported the commissionâ€™s finding that Towerâ€™s claim was barred by the horseplay defense.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Tower related the following version of the incident:Â  While doing paperwork at her desk, she had soaked her hand in a cup of water because of a paper cut on her finger.Â  When she stopped soaking her hand, she stood and extended her hand to flick the water off to avoid getting water on her computer or paperwork.Â  About the same time, Thomas McQueen, an administrative manager at the Department, was meeting with Towerâ€™s supervisor near Towerâ€™s workstation.Â  Although Tower did not intend to hit anyone with the water, some that she flicked off her fingers hit McQueen.Â  McQueen then entered Towerâ€™s work station, sat in Towerâ€™s chair, grabbed Tower by the arms, threw her across his lap, and spanked her.Â  Tower tried to get away and screamed at McQueen to stop.Â  Tower sustained an injury to her neck from the incident.Â  The injury resulted in her having an anterior cervical discectomy and fusion on January 29, 2003.Â  Tower also missed work from the latter date until February 27, 2003, after which she returned to work part-time for four weeks.Â  
McQueen and Sammie Metts, Towerâ€™s supervisor, gave a different account of the incident.Â  They both contended that Tower called McQueen over and began flicking drops of water at him from across her desk.Â  Both also stated that McQueen and Tower had teased each other on previous occasions.Â  
Tower filed a Form 50 seeking workersâ€™ compensation benefits, alleging she was injured in the course of her employment on October 30, 2002.Â  The Department filed a Form 51 with the commission denying Towerâ€™s injuries were compensable.Â  
The single commissioner awarded Tower workersâ€™ compensation benefits, finding McQueen was the aggressor by making â€œa wholly inappropriate response to [Towerâ€™s] action of flicking water.â€Â  The Department appealed, and by a two-to-one vote, an appellate panel of the commission reversed the single commissionerâ€™s order, finding (1) Tower was injured as the result of her instigation of horseplay; (2) both Tower and McQueen had behaved inappropriately; and (3) although McQueenâ€™s actions were inappropriate to a greater degree than Towerâ€™s, his culpability did not alter the fact that Tower had been the instigator.Â  Tower then appealed to the circuit court, which upheld the order of the commission, finding all activity of both Tower and McQueen constituted horseplay and had been instigated by Tower.[2]Â  
DISCUSSION
1.Â  We hold the circuit court correctly determined substantial evidence supported the commissionâ€™s findings that Tower engaged in horseplay and that Towerâ€™s conduct barred her from recovering workersâ€™ compensation benefits.
â€œHorseplay is a term used to describe â€˜pranks and practical jokes which are frequently indulged in by congregated workmen.â€[3]Â  Concerning horseplay, â€œ[c]ourts generally distinguish between aggressors or instigators, who are not compensated when injured, and nonparticipating victims or innocent bystanders who are compensated.â€[4] 
Tower stated her paper cut was under her fingernail and agreed â€œthe natural thingâ€ for her to do would have been to place only her fingertips in the water.Â  Nevertheless, she conceded that she soaked her entire hand in the cup.Â  Moreover, contrary to Towerâ€™s statements that she never intended to flick water onto anyone, McQueen testified Tower began flicking water onto him only after he approached Towerâ€™s work area at her behest and, as he moved from the front of Towerâ€™s desk to the other side, she continued to flick water onto him, laughing and â€œcutting up.â€Â  Even as McQueen was walking away, Tower continued to flick water onto him.Â  McQueen further stated that he would not have gone behind Towerâ€™s desk if she had not flicked water onto him.Â  Metts, who witnessed the entire incident, confirmed McQueenâ€™s version of the events. 
In support of her argument that the commissionâ€™s finding that she instigated horseplay was not supported by substantial evidence, Tower argues (1) her actions were brief, innocuous, and non-aggressive and therefore do not rise to the level of horseplay; and (2) McQueenâ€™s misconduct was â€œseparatedâ€ from hers and â€œwas significantly more extreme than her minimal acts of teasing.â€Â  The circuit court did not address either of these arguments and the record does not show that Tower made a post-trial for the necessary rulings; therefore, they are not preserved for appeal.[5]
2.Â  Tower also contends the denial of compensation was premised on an error of law.Â  In conjunction with this argument, she notes the South Carolina workersâ€™ compensation statutes do not provide an express exception to coverage for the horseplay defense.Â  She also suggests public policy warrants reexamination of the application of the horseplay defense in workers compensation cases.Â  Because, however, none of these issues were addressed by the circuit court in the appealed order, they are not preserved for our review in this appeal.[6]
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  In a handwritten order issued from the bench, the presiding circuit judge stated that, although he disagreed with the full commission, he found its decision was supported by substantial evidence.Â  
[3]Â  Floyd v. City of Charleston, 287 S.C. 474, 477 n.2, 339 S.E.2d 166, 167 n.2 (Ct. App. 1986) (citing Allsep v. Daniel Constr. Co., 216 S.C. 268, 273, 57 S.E.2d 427, 429 (1950)).
[4]Â  Allsep v. Daniel Constr. Co., 216 S.C. 268, 273, 57 S.E.2d. 427, 429 (1950) (emphasis added).
[5]Â  See Pratt v. Morris Roofing Co., 353 S.C. 339, 352, 577 S.E.2d 475, 481-82 (Ct. App. 2003) (holding an issue in a workers compensation case was not preserved for appellate review because it was not ruled on by the commissioner, the full commission, or the circuit court), affâ€™d as modified, 357 S.C. 619, 594 S.E.2d 271 (2004).
[6]Â  See id.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Terrance V. Smith, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Lexington County
Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-600
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 30, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Mary P. Miles, of West Columbia; for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Terrance V. Smith and a codefendant were convicted in a joint trial for the offenses of murder, assault and battery with intent to kill, conspiracy and attempted armed robbery.Â  Smith appeals his convictions and argues the trial court erred in: (1) failing to grant his motion to sever; (2) failing to grant various motions in connection with the testimony of John Hayward; (3) failing to instruct the jury on self-defense; and (4) failing to grant motions for a directed verdict or a new trial.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR.
1.Â Â The trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying Smithâ€™s motion to sever his trial from that of his codefendant. Smithâ€™s various arguments find no traction in this record and provide no basis for reversal.Â  State v. Dennis, 337 S.C. 275, 281, 523 S.E.2d 173, 176 (1999) (noting that defendants jointly tried for murder are not entitled to separate trials as a matter of right; the rule permitting â€œjoint trials applies with equal force when a defendantâ€™s severance motion is based upon the likelihood he and a codefendant will present mutually antagonistic defensesâ€); State v. Avery, 333 S.C. 284, 294-95, 509 S.E.2d 476, 482 (1998) (finding no abuse of discretion in denial of severance and observing that â€œif appellant had been tried separately from [his codefendant], the same evidence could have been presentedâ€); State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 122, 481 S.E.2d 118, 124 (1997) (noting that a motion for severance and separate trial is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court and such determination will be sustained absent an abuse of discretion).
2.Â Â The challenge to the admissibility of John Haywardâ€™s in-court identification of Smith is without merit.Â  State v. Traylor, 360 S.C. 74, 81-83, 600 S.E.2d 523, 527-28 (2004) (finding identification reliable and admissible notwithstanding suggestive procedure where witness had opportunity to observe and expressed high level of certainty); State v. Moore, 343 S.C. 282, 286-87, 540 S.E.2d 445, 447-48 (2000) (noting that an in-court identification is inadmissible if a suggestive out-of-court identification created a substantial likelihood of misidentification, and that such inquiry entails consideration of the totality of the circumstances); State v. Brown, 356 S.C. 496, 504,Â  589 S.E.2d 781, 785 (Ct. App. 2003) (noting that the factors to consider when assessing the reliability of an identification include opportunity to view the crime, degree of attention, accuracy of prior description, level of certainty and amount of time from crime to confrontation); State v. Tisdale, 338 S.C. 607, 611, 527 S.E.2d 389, 391-92 (Ct. App. 2000) (finding that the admission of identification evidence is within the discretion of the trial court, and the trial courtâ€™s determination will not be reversed absent a showing of error and prejudice).Â  Even assuming, however, error in the admission of Haywardâ€™s in-court identification of Smith, we are firmly convinced that such error would be harmless in view of the other evidence of Smithâ€™s guilt.Â  State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 144-45, 591 S.E.2d 646, 653 (Ct. App. 2004) (noting that â€œerror is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial â€¦ [and that] [t]he admission of improper evidence is harmless where the evidence is merely cumulative to other evidenceâ€).Â  In connection with the remaining assignments of error concerning Haywardâ€™s testimony: State v. Hughes, 336 S.C. 585, 597,Â  521 S.E.2d 500, 506 (1999) (â€œThe decision whether to grant a mistrial because of a witnessâ€™s outburst rests within the sound discretion of the trial judge and will not be reversed absent an abuse thereof or manifest prejudice to the complaining party.â€); State v. Needs, 333 S.C. 134, 144, 508 S.E.2d 857, 862 (1998) (â€œâ€˜[T]his Court has more than once held that the jury is the judge of which contradictory statement of the witness is the truth.â€™â€ (quoting Soulios v. Mills Novelty Co., 198 S.C. 355, 364, 17 S.E.2d 869, 874 (1941))); Â State v. Jones, 325 S.C. 310, 318, 479 S.E.2d 517, 521 (Ct. App. 1996) (holding that â€œverdicts should not be set aside by an appellate court for misconduct in a trial, unless the evidence is clear and convincing that extraneous influences so interfered with the conduct of the trial, or so pressed upon the jury, as to become factors in the resultâ€); 98 C.J.S. Witnesses Â§ 103 (2002) (noting that false statements in a witnessâ€™s testimony â€œis considered relevant only to the extent it affects credibility, not competenceâ€); See In re Robert M, 294 S.C. 69, 70-71, 362 S.E.2d 639, 640-41 (1987) (finding that the determination of a witnessâ€™s competency rests in the discretion of the trial judge, whose decision will be affirmed absent an abuse of discretion).
3.Â Â Smithâ€™s alleged error in the trial courtâ€™s failure to charge self-defense is not preserved for appellate review, for no such request was made in the trial court.Â  State v. Hicks, 330 S.C. 207, 214, 499 S.E.2d 209, 217 (1998) (finding that a failure to request specific instruction waives right to challenge issue on appeal).
4.Â Â The trial court properly denied Smithâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.Â  State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 62, 502 S.E.2d 63, 69 (1998) (finding that on a directed verdict motion in a criminal case, the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the State).Â  There was no error in the denial of the motion for a new trial, as the motion merely incorporated the various objections and challenges made during the trial.[1]
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
