THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Douglas N. Yarborough, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Anita J. Yarborough, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Lexington County
Richard W. Chewning, III, Family Court Judge

 Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-601 
Heard October 12, 2005 â€“Filed November 30, 2005

AFFIRMED as MODIFIED


  
    
      
        Jon T. Clabaugh, Jr. and Kathryne A. Shelton, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Cynthia B. Castengera of Newland, N.C., and Michael Jeffcoat, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Anita J. Yarborough appeals the family court order: denying her custody of the minor children, limiting her visitation, calculating child support payments, dividing the debt and marital assets, refusing alimony and rejecting her demand for assistance with attorneysâ€™ fees and guardian ad litem fees.Â Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTS
Anita and Douglas Yarborough were lawfully married on June 20, 1993 in Lexington County, South Carolina.Â  The parties ceased living together in January of 2001.Â  A divorce was granted on October 14, 2003, to Douglas Yarborough on the basis of continuous separation without cohabitation for one year.Â  
Originally, Anita had custody of their children, Adam and Katilin, and Douglas paid child support.Â  Douglas left Anita and the children in the marital home.Â  When asked why he left the children with their mother, he stated, â€œI was hoping that, if I left, if I moved out in January [2001], that she would stay here in South Carolina so I could see my kids.â€ However in August of 2001, Anita and the children moved to Humble, Texas to live with her parents.Â  Anita claimed the move was for financial reasons, because she was unemployed.Â  Douglas had telephone visitation every Tuesday and Thursday night from 7 p.m. to 8 p.m. Eastern Standard Time and visitation privileges every Christmas and summer.
In Texas, the mother and children lived in a trailer with Anitaâ€™s mother, step-father, sister, brother and the brotherâ€™s girlfriend.Â  Adam began experiencing some behavior problems.Â  Anita had difficulty getting the children home to talk to their father at the scheduled time.Â  She blamed this on the fact that Texas was in the Central Time Zone.Â  Consequently, telephone visitation became sporadic.Â  In November of 2000, seven-year-old Adam crashed an ATV into Billy Harwellâ€™s truck.Â  This caused significant damage to the vehicle.Â  He was neither supervised at the time of the accident nor taken to the doctor after the crash took place.Â  Adamâ€™s father did not know about the accident until Mr. Harwell contacted him.Â  In August of 2002, Anita and her brother, Rusty, were involved in a physical altercation at the house in Texas.Â  Anita called the police, and Rusty was thrown out of the house by his mother.Â  According to Adam, Rusty grabbed Adam by the neck and swung him around the room.Â  Douglas was unaware of this event until Adam later told him about it over the phone.Â  
Douglas scheduled a time to pick up his children on December 21, 2002, for Christmas vacation.Â  Douglas and Anita planned to meet halfway at a police station in Mobile, Alabama, but Anita was over two hours late. Douglas could not get in touch with her or her family, and Anita did not attempt to contact him.Â  After filing a police report, he returned to South Carolina.Â Â  
An Ex Parte Order granting an Emergency or Expedited Hearing was filed on January 15, 2003.Â  Douglas received custody of his children.Â  On February 27, 2003, an order was filed awarding temporary custody of the children to the father until the final divorce proceeding.Â  
The family court granted custody to the father, concluding this would be in the best interest of both children.Â  The mother was granted telephone visitation, Christmas, summer and spring break visitation.Â  Furthermore, she is allowed to see her children for reasonable periods of overnight visitation when she is in South Carolina.Â  The family court imputed a $930.00 per month minimum wage to Anita, who was unemployed at the time of the trial.Â  Anita owes $304.85 per month in child support to be paid to the Clerk of Court of Lexington with a 5% handling fee.Â  The court found the marital debt, property and Guardian ad Litem fees should be divided in half.Â  Additionally, the court found each party responsible for their own attorneysâ€™ fees.
STANDARD OF REVIEW 
Â In family court appeals, this court may find facts in agreement with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Lanier v. Lanier, 364 S.C. 211, 612 S.E.2d 456 (Ct. App. 2005); Nasser-Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, 364 S.C.182, 612 S.E.2d 707 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Regardless of our broad scope of review however, we are not required to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 561 S.E.2d 610 (Ct. App. 1999); Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 522 S.E.2d 835 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Nor do we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate the credibility and assign comparative weight to the witnessesâ€™ testimony.Â  Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302, 608 S.E.2d 147 (Ct. App. 2005); Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C.322, 526 S.E.2d 241 (Ct. App. 1999); see also Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 477 S.E.2d 476 (Ct. App. 1996) (noting that because the appellate court lacks the opportunity for direct observation of witnesses, it should accord great deference to the family courtâ€™s findings where matters of credibility are involved).Â  An appellate court â€œshould be reluctant to substitute its own evaluation of the evidence on child custody for that of the trial court.â€ Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  However, when the best interests of the child are compromised by the family courtâ€™s visitation schedule, we have the ability to use de novo review.Â  Arnal v. Arnal, 363 S.C. 268, 609 S.E.2d 821 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The burden weighs heavily on the appellant who must convince this Court the family court committed error.Â  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-523, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979). 
DISCUSSION
I. Custody
Anita Yarborough argues that the family court erred in awarding custody to Douglas Yarborough.Â  We disagree. 
The most important and controlling factor in every custody dispute is the best interests of the children.Â  Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 330, 536 S.E.2d 427, 430 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Parapella v. Parapella, 340 S.C. 186, 189 531 S.E.2d 297, 299 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  However many aspects must be considered to determine the best interests of a child and thus the outcome of a child custody case.Â  Pirayesh v. Pirayesh, 359 S.C. 284, 596 S.E.2d 505 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œIn reaching a determination as to custody, the family court should consider how the custody decision will impact all areas of the childâ€™s life, including physical, psychological, spiritual, educational, familial, emotional and recreational aspects.â€Â  Shirley, 342 S.C. at 330, 536 S.E.2d at 430.Â  â€œAdditionally, the court must assess each partyâ€™s character, fitness and attitude as they impact the child.â€ Id.Â  The Pirayesh court noted that the opinions of third parties (including the guardian, expert witnesses, and the children) should be taken into account when determining custody.Â  Furthermore this court must consider that in South Carolina, there is a presumption against moving children out of the state.Â  Rice v. Rice, 335 S.C. 449, 454, 517 S.E.2d 220, 222 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The court must determine if moving is in the best interest of the child. Id.
Extensive testimony was presented regarding the parenting habits and practices of both parents.Â  Jack Justice, a licensed social worker, and Sheila M. Robinson, the Guardian ad Litem, testified.Â  Justice, a therapist at the Columbia Counseling Center, was qualified as an expert witness in the field of therapy.Â  Justice met with Adam, Katilin and Douglas approximately ten times before the trial.Â  Justice testified that â€œ[Douglas Yarborough] is a good father.Â  I think he has his childrenâ€™s best interest [sic] at heart.â€Â  Moreover, Robinson reported that both (Anitaâ€™s and Douglasâ€™s) homes were suitable, and that both were good parents.Â  Daycare workers vouched for the improvement in Katilinâ€™s behavior since moving in with her father.Â  Adam made excellent progress in school after relocating.Â  The family court did not err in determining that the best interests of the children would be served by giving the father custody.Â  
II. Limiting visitation 
Anita Yarborough appeals the visitation parameters set forth by the trial court, specifically the time and type of visitation and transportation costs. 
As always â€œwhen awarding visitation, the controlling consideration is the welfare and best interest[s] of the child[ren].â€Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 12, 471 S.E.2d 154, 158 (1996).Â  â€œA family court may impose upon a non-custodial parent such conditions and restrictions on visitation privileges as the court in its discretion, thinks proper.â€ Frye v. Frye, 323 S.C. 72, 448 S.E.2d 586 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  â€œ[D]etermining and limiting visitation rights is in the broad discretion of the trial judge, and in the absence of a clear abuse of such, the order granting, denying or limiting visitation rights will not be disturbed.â€ Graham v. Graham, 253 S.C. 486, 171 S.E.2d 704 (1970).Â  Furthermore this court must recognize that â€œ[v]isitation arrangements are not allowed that involve excessive shuttling of the children between parents.â€Â  Mixson v. Mixson, 253 S.C. 436, 171 S.E.2d 581 (1969).Â  Thus, when the best interests of the children are compromised by the family courtâ€™s visitation schedule, we have the ability to use de novo review.Â  Arnal, 363 S.C. at 291, 609 S.E.2d at 833 (Ct. App. 2005).
Anita chose to live in Humble, Texas, which is roughly seventeen hours and one thousand miles away from her children.Â  The trial court awarded four weeks of visitation with Anita in Texas, divided into two (2) two-week visits.Â  Under these circumstances, this constitutes excessive shuttling of the children between South Carolina and Texas.Â  As an alternative, Anita should have one five-week period of visitation each summer, not to include the week after school ends or the week before school begins.Â  Anita shall provide Douglas with notice of which weeks she is choosing for visitation via registered mail no later than April 1 of each year.Â  In addition, we find it to be in the childrenâ€™s best interests for Anita to have telephone contact.Â  Anita is entitled to telephone contact beginning at 8:30 p.m. Eastern Standard Time each Tuesday and Thursday.Â  Anita is responsible for initiating the calls.Â  During the five (5) weeks of summer visitation with Anita, Douglas shall have the same right of telephone contact with the children.Â  During this time Douglas will be responsible for initiating the calls.Â  This court declines to further modify the visitation. 
III. Calculating child support 
Anita argues that the family court erred in imputing her child support obligation.Â  We disagree. 
S.C. Code Ann.Â  Â§ 20-7-90 (1976) provides in part:

  (A) Any able-bodied person capable of earning a livelihood who shall, without just cause or excuse, abandon or fail to provide reasonable support to his or her spouse or to his or her minor unmarried legitimate or illegitimate child dependent on him or her shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor . . . .

The factors to be considered in establishing child support obligations include: both parentsâ€™ income, ability to pay, education, expenses, and assets, as well as the facts and circumstances surrounding each case.Â  Mitchell v. Mitchell, 283 S.C. 87, 320 S.E.2d 706 (1989).Â  â€œThe award should be an amount that the parent can pay and still meet his or her own needs.â€ Smith v. Delaney, 286 S.C. 583, 334 S.E.2d 821 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  
The judge used the South Carolina Child Support Guidelines to calculate the amount of child support Anita owed each month.Â  According to Guidelines, Section III (A) (5):

  If the court finds that a parent is voluntarily unemployed or underemployed, it should calculate child support based on a determination of potential income which would otherwise ordinarily be available to the parent.

Prior to moving to Texas, Anita worked for the State of South Carolina.Â  After her move, she worked for a temporary agency and for her mother.Â Â  Although at trial she was unemployed, the judge correctly imputed that Anita was able to earn a minimum wage.Â  Anita has a duty to support her children.Â  
IV.  Division of debt and marital assets
Anita Yarborough contends that the family court erred in the division of the marital property and debts.Â  We disagree. 
â€œThe doctrine of equitable distribution is based on a recognition that marriage is, among other things, an economic partnership.â€ Mallett v. Mallett, 323 S.C. 141, 150, 473 S.E.2d 804, 810 (Ct. App. 1996). â€œUpon dissolution of the marriage, marital property should be divided and distributed in a manner which fairly reflects each spouseâ€™s contribution to its acquisition, regardless of who holds legal title.â€ Morris v. Morris, 335 S.C. 525, 531, 517 S.E.2d 720, 723 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In making an equitable distribution of marital property, the family court must, among other things: (1) identify the marital property, both real and personal, to be divided between the parties; (2) determine the fair market value of the identified property; (3) apportion the marital estate according to the contributions, both direct and indirect, of each party to the acquisition of the property during the marriage, their respective assets and incomes, and any special equities they may have in marital assets; and (4) provide for an equitable division of the marital estate, including the manner in which the distribution is to take place. Noll v. Noll, 297 S.C. 190, 375 S.E.2d 338 (Ct. App. 1988).
The only marital property owned by the parties is real property located at 5736 Augusta Highway in Leesville, South Carolina.Â  The value of this property is Thirty-One Thousand Five Hundred Dollars and 00/100 ($31,500.00).Â  The equity in the home is Five Thousand Five Hundred and 00/100 ($5,500.00).Â  Anita will receive a check from Douglas in the amount of Two Thousand Seven Hundred and Fifty Dollars and 00/100 ($2,750.00).Â  We affirm the family courtâ€™s division of property and the manner of distribution.
V. Alimony
Anita asserts that the family court erred by not awarding her alimony.Â  We disagree. 
No issue may be raised for the first time on appeal, instead it must have been raised at trial in order to preserve the issue for appeal.Â  State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 481 S.E.2d 118 (1997).Â  Even if the issue were preserved, â€œ[t]he decision to grant or deny alimony is within the sound discretion of the family court judge, whose decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion.â€Â  Hatfield v. Hatfield, 327 S.C. 360, 364, 489 S.E.2d 212, 215 (Ct. App. 1997) (citing Williamson v. Williamson, 311 S.C. 47, 426 S.E.2d 758 (1993)).Â  
The S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C)(Supp. 2003) states:

  The family court must consider and give weight in such proportion as it finds appropriate to the following factors in determining an award of alimony: (1) duration of the marriage and ages of the parties at the time of the marriage and divorce; (2)physical and emotional condition of the parties; (3) educational background and need for additional education of the parties; (4) employment history and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living established during the marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated income of the parties; (7) current and reasonably anticipated expenses and needs of the parties; (8) marital and non-marital properties of the parties; (9) custody of the children; (10) marital misconduct or fault that affects the economic circumstances of the parties or contributes to the break-up of the marriage; (11) tax consequences of the reward; (12) prior support obligations of the parties; and (13) other factors the court considers relevant. 

Anita and Douglas were married for approximately ten years, living together for about eight and a half years.Â  Both were around thirty-one years of age at the time of the divorce.Â  The physical and emotional state of each party was not discussed at trial, although it was evident that both were physically healthy and neither one wanted to reconcile the marriage.Â  Anita testified that she graduated from college in 1993, although she never specified what college she attended or what degree she received.Â  Anita and Douglas have employment history, and each have the potential to find and continue employment based on their job history.Â  The standard of living as established during the marriage has remained unchanged for both parties.Â  After the birth of their children, Anita did not work.Â  Douglas has custody; therefore, her expenses should be less.Â  Fault was not an issue at the trial.Â  The trial judge did not abuse his discretion by failing to award Anita alimony. 
VI.  Attorneysâ€™ fees and guardian ad litem fees
Anita appeals the failure of the family court to award her attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  Additionally, she attacks the division of the Guardian ad Litem fees.
The award of attorneyâ€™s fees is at the sound discretion of the family court. Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 368 S.E.2d 901 (1988).Â  In deciding whether to award attorneysâ€™ fees, the family court should consider: (1) the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fees; (2) the beneficial results obtained by counsel; (3) the respective financial conditions of the parties; and (4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living. E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 415 S.E.2d 812 (1992); Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 536 S.E.2d 427.Â  Our Supreme Court has identified the following factors for determining a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee: (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional standing of counsel; (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; and (6) customary legal fees for similar services. Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991).
Although she is unemployed, Anita has marketable job skills.Â Â Â  Douglas has retained his job with Cooper Power Tools for over 6 years.Â  The father received custody of the two minor children thus maintaining his standard of living prior to the divorce.Â  Anita ameliorated her financial difficulty by moving in with her parents in Texas.Â  Neither partyâ€™s standard of living changed as a result of the divorce, nor was the divorce granted on a fault basis.Â  This case was not overly difficult and did not present any novel issues of law.Â  Both parties have the ability to work and to pay attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  Therefore, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in deciding each party would bear his or her own attorneyâ€™s fees and costs. 
An award of GAL fees lies within the sound discretion of the family court judge and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 341, 536 S.E.2d 427, 436.Â  In the present case, the GAL completed an independent, balanced, and impartial investigation, as is required by the court.Â  The GAL reduced her rate to $110.00 per hour.Â  She conducted home visits in South Carolina and Texas.Â  She interviewed 23 witnesses.Â  Her fee requirement is fair and should not create a hardship.Â  
CONCLUSION
 Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s ruling is 
AFFIRMED as MODIFIED.
ANDERSON, HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concurÂ

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Danny R. Prince, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Beaufort Memorial Hospital and its Employees, Servants and Agents, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â  Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge
Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge
Curtis L. Coltrane, Master in Equity and Special Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-602Â Â  
Heard October 12, 2005 â€“ Filed November 30, 2005
Withdrawn, Substituted, and Refiled April 11, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Terry Wayne Yarbrough, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
        James S. Gibson, Jr., and Mary Bass Lohr, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Danny Prince appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of several motions in conjunction with his medical malpractice case against Beaufort Memorial Hospital.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
Beaufort Memorial Hospital (the Hospital) admitted Prince on February 13, 1999, with job related injuries.Â  From that day until the night of February 17, Prince was a compliant patient who exhibited no signs of abnormal or psychotic behavior.Â  Sometime after 10:30 p.m. on February 17, Prince apparently experienced a psychotic hallucination in his hospital room.Â  
At 11:20 p.m., Hospital staff found Prince on the roof of the second floor with injuries to his ankles and head resulting from an apparent fall or jump from his fourth floor room.Â  Although Prince does not remember anything from the incident, including how he got out of his room or onto the roof, the window in his room showed signs of being forced open.Â  
Pat Foulger is the Hospitalâ€™s Vice President and holds positions on many Hospital committees including the P.I. or Quality Assurance Committee (hereafter the â€œQuality Assurance Committeeâ€).Â  The Quality Assurance Committee investigated the incident involving Prince.Â  Counsel for Prince requested a copy of the file created during the investigation.Â  The Hospital answered by providing a summary of expected witness testimony, but refused to turn over the file claiming it was protected under South Carolina Code Sections 40-71-10 & 20 (2001 & Supp. 2004).Â  The circuit court denied Princeâ€™s motions to compel discovery of the complete file.Â  Following trial the jury returned a defense verdict.Â  Thereafter, Prince filed timely motions requesting a judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV) and a new trial, which were denied.Â  
ISSUES

  
    I.  
    Was the trial court correct in ruling the Hospital’s Quality Assurance Committee file was confidential and thus, not subject to discovery under Section 40-71-10 & 20?  
    
  
  
    II.  
    Was the trial court correct in declining to entertain an in camera review of the alleged confidential committee file?
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Confidentiality
The Hospital claims that Sections 40-71-10 & 40-71-20 of the South Carolina Code protect the file in dispute.Â  Prince argues that the file was not protected because the Quality Assurance Committee did not meet the conditions of confidentiality as set out in Section 40-71-10.Â  Section 40-71-10 (a) states:

  â€œProfessional societyâ€ as used in this chapter includes legal, medical, osteopathic, optometric, chiropractic, psychological, dental, accounting, pharmaceutic, and engineering organizations having as members at least a majority of the eligible licentiates in the area served by the particular society and any foundations composed of members of these societies. It also includes the South Carolina Law Enforcement Accreditation Council.

Further, Section 40-71-10 (b) provides immunity for:

  an appointed member of a committee of a medical staff of a licensed hospital, provided the medical staff operates pursuant to written bylaws that have been approved by the governing board of the hospital . . . for any act or proceeding undertaken or performed within the scope of the functions of the committee.

In this case the record shows that the Quality Assurance Committee operates pursuant to bylaws.Â  Prince argues no evidence was presented to show that a majority of the Committee members were licentiates.Â  However, Ms. Foulgerâ€™s deposition testimony states that the Quality Assurance Committee has three medical staff members and three board members, one of which is a physician.Â  Ms. Foulger testifies that the committee is made up of about 50% licensed medical personnel.Â  
The plain language of Section 40-71-10 provides that a committee, acting pursuant to bylaws, at a hospital or in a medical field, will be exempt from tort liability.Â  The Hospitalâ€™s Committee is the type described in Taylor v. Medenica, 324 S.C. 200, 213, 479 S.E.2d 35, 42 (1996).Â  In that case, Dr. Medenica claimed that there was a committee and its file was privileged.Â  The court acknowledged that a peer review committee file would be confidential, but found that the information used during trial came from an independent source.Â  Also, a similar committee has been held by our supreme court to be protected by Sections 40-71-10 & 20 in McGee v. Bruce Hospital System, 312 S.C. 58, 61, 439 S.E.2d 257, 259 (1993).Â  Therefore, we find that there was evidence that the committee in question met the specifications of Section 40-71-10.Â  
Section 40-71-20 provides in pertinent part:

  All proceedings of and all data and information acquired by the committee referred to in Section 40-71-10 in the exercise of its duties are confidential unless a respondent in the proceeding requests in writing that they be made public. These proceedings and documents are not subject to discovery, subpoena, or introduction into evidence in any civil action except upon appeal from the committee action. Information, documents, or records which are otherwise available from original sources are not immune from discovery or use in a civil action merely because they were presented during the committee proceedings nor shall any complainant or witness before the committee be prevented from testifying in a civil action as to matters of which he has knowledge apart from the committee proceedings or revealing such matters to third persons. 

Prince argues that no witnesses ever appeared before any committee.Â  While this assertion is true and reflected in the record, there is also evidence that Pat Foulger talked to witnesses in an informal setting, collected incident reports, and obtained statements from the hospital personnel involved in Princeâ€™s incident.Â  The statute protects information that is acquired by a committee.Â  Section 40-71-20 does not require witnesses to appear before the whole committee in order to satisfy the confidentiality requirements.Â  
Prince was, however, entitled to documents recording the outcome of the quality assurance review pursuant to McGee.Â  See McGee, 312 S.C. 58, 63, 439 S.E.2d 257, 260 (1993) (holding â€œthe outcome of the decision-making process is not protected.â€).Â  Judge Gregory denied Prince this specific discovery request.Â  While this is error, it is not prejudicial error in light of the fact that the Hospital confirmed in their answers to interrogatories that â€œno one was suspended, charged or cited with any violation of hospital rules, standards, laws, policy or procedures as a result of the [Prince incident].â€Â  
Sections 40-71-10 & 20 have been the subject of only a few cases on appeal.Â  The first one, the McGee case, was granted certiorari to the South Carolina Supreme Court in 1993 as a novel issue of law.Â  Following McGee, this issue was briefly considered in the Taylor case in 1996.Â  The last case dealing with Sections 40-71-10 and 20 is Durham v. Vinson, 360 S.C. 639, 602 S.E.2d 760 (2004).Â  McGee, Taylor, and Durham all involve medical malpractice claims seeking disclosure of the doctorsâ€™ applications for staff privileges, whereas this case involves an accident at the Hospital.Â  Nevertheless, the statute was written broadly enough to protect all proceedings and all information acquired by a committee during an investigation. 
â€œThe overriding public policy of the confidentiality statute is to encourage health care professionals to monitor the competency and professional conduct of their peers to safeguard and improve the quality of patient care.â€Â  See McGee 312 S.C. at Â­Â­Â­Â­61, 439 S.E.2d at 259.Â  The Hospital in this case was investigating the Prince incident in order to monitor its own actions, and to take steps to further protect its patients.Â  Sections 40-71-10 & 20 provide safeguards to hospitals while conducting this exact type of investigation. 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  In Camera Review
Prince also argues that the trial judge erred in failing to review the committee file in camera.Â  The trial judge found the file was confidential and thus declined to review it.Â  After our review of the record, however, we feel the nature of this case demands an in camera review of the file.Â  Prince had no memory of the incident, and the only investigative body was the Hospital, a naturally biased entity.Â  In camera reviews should be used liberally to guard against even a mere possibility a miscarriage of justice will occur.Â  Therefore, it was error for the trial judge to decline to review the Hospitalâ€™s Quality Assurance Committee file.[1]
On remand the circuit court shall conduct an in camera review of the committee file.Â  Using its discretion, the court shall decide whether the file warrants confidentiality.Â  If the circuit court determines that the file contains relevant evidence which is not protected by the confidentiality statute, then it shall declare a new trial.Â  Alternatively, if the circuit court determines that there is no relevant evidence in the committee file or that the file is entitled to the protections of the confidentiality statute, then the original denial of a new trial and JNOV motion would be affirmed.
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON, HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur

[1] During the 2005 legislative session, the General Assembly amended Chapter 71, Title 40 of the 1976 Code by adding Section 40-71-30 which provides:

  When a party asserts a claim of confidentiality over documents pursuant to Section 40-71-20 and the party seeking the documents objects, the documents must be filed under seal with the circuit court having jurisdiction over the pending action and are subject to judicial review by the circuit court judge.Â  If the court determines that any of the documents are not subject to confidentiality pursuant to Section 40-71-20 and are otherwise discoverable, the court shall provide the documents to the requesting party.Â  In the event the court finds that a party acted unreasonably in unsuccessfully asserting the claim of confidentiality, the court shall assess attorneyâ€™s fees against that party for any fees incurred by the requesting party in obtaining the documents.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Robert Calvin Vaughn, by Faye Vaughn, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Salem Carriers, Employer and Virginia Surety Company, Carrier, Appellants.
          
        
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-603
Submitted November 1, 2005 â€“ Filed November 30, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Kay G. Crowe and Andrea C. Pope, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Joseph Collins Smithdeal, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation action, Salem Carriers and Virginia Surety Carrier appeal the trial courtâ€™s order affirming the order of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Commission), which awarded benefits to Faye Vaughn for the death of her husband, Robert Vaughn.Â  We affirm.1
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Salem Carriers employed Robert primarily as a drop and hook driver from December 1996 until his death on July 7, 1999.Â  As a drop and hook driver, Robert transported box trailers filled with textiles from the Sara Lee plant in Hodges, South Carolina to another plant location, dropped off the trailer, picked up a trailer, and then returned to the plant in Hodges.Â  A drop and hook operation is considered light duty work for a truck driver. Â 
During the week of July 1 through 7 of 1999, the Sara Lee plants were shut down and Robert was not scheduled to drive.Â  Robert agreed, however, to substitute as a flatbed truck driver for Salem Carrierâ€™s RMAX account.Â  Driving a flatbed truck typically requires more physical activity than a drop and hook operation of dropping off and hooking up to loads.Â  Flatbed driving often involves securing the load, requiring tarping, climbing, and strapping by the driver.Â  The strapping and tarping occurs after the truck has been loaded, and the loading usually takes fifteen to twenty minutes for a load the size of the one Robert was driving.Â  One of the drivers who Robert substituted for at the time of his death, Eugene Miller, testified about the normal process for securing a load.Â  Miller testified that at the RMAX plant, if he was present he would observe the product being loaded, but sometimes it was loaded without him being there.Â  In securing the load, a driver first has to throw six or seven straps over the load.Â  He then has to climb up a thirteen-foot ladder, which is like an airplane ladder, onto the top of the load and get on his hands and knees in order to straighten the straps.Â  He would stand up to go to the next strap and then get down on his hands and knees again.Â  He would also put corner pieces on to keep the load from being damaged.Â  He then climbs back down the ladder and hooks the straps and tightens them with a metal bar.Â  Finally, the driver would usually put a tarp weighing twenty to thirty pounds, over the load, climb back up the ladder, and then spread the tarp over the load. He would then secure the tarp by hooking thirty or forty bungee cords onto the tarp, tighten the cords, and then hook them to the side of the trailer.Â  The strapping and tarping normally takes from thirty minutes to an hour and fifteen minutes, depending on the driver.Â  
While working for Salem Carriers, Robert drove a flatbed truck only three days in 1998 and for two days in July 1999 before the day of his death.Â  It is undisputed Robert was a drop and hook driver, as opposed to a flatbed driver, ninety-eight to ninety-nine percent of the time he was employed with Salem Carriers.Â  When Robert came home after his first day as a substitute driver during the first week of July, 1999, his wife testified that he was dragging, gray, ashy, and sweating.Â  After he worked July 1 and 2, he was off for a long weekend.Â  Over that weekend he did a little painting and wallpapering, and cut the grass with a riding mower, but did not perform any strenuous activities.Â  According to Fayeâ€™s testimony, on July 6, Robert arrived home early and appeared normal.Â  Robertâ€™s log sheet indicated he was present at the RMAX plant from ten in the morning until noon that day.Â  The log sheet does not specify what he was doing at the plant for that time and the parties dispute whether the truck was loaded and Robert secured it on that date or whether the truck may have just been loaded then.Â  
The record shows on July 7, Robert was at the RMAX plant for approximately one hour and twenty-three minutes before he left the plant with his secured load.Â  At 9:08 a.m., after driving from the RMAX plant in Greer into downtown Greenville, Vaughn called for an ambulance.Â  Once it arrived, he told the emergency medical technician that he began having chest pains while he was securing his load around 8:00 that morning.Â  Robert was taken to the emergency room and died that same day from cardiac arrest.Â  
Miller testified it was not unusual on this route for a truck to be loaded and left overnight without it having been strapped or tarped by the driver.Â  He further stated, based on his experience, he believed Robert did not take possession and control of the load until July 7, when he signed the bill of lading, and that he was of the opinion Robert spent the morning of July 7 at the RMAX plant securing his load.Â  Miller also opined that for the two hours Robert was at RMAX on July 6, he was waiting to get his truck loaded.Â  David Doherty, who was presented as an expert witness in the field of trucking operations, testified that during the two hours Robert was at the plant on July 6, he could have been repositioning his trailer, performing an inspection on his trailer, or waiting for it to be loaded but encountered a problem and the loading was not completed.Â  He stated that trailers like this could be loaded in the driverâ€™s absence.Â  Doherty was of the opinion Robert was hooking up his trailer and strapping and tarping his load on the morning of his death.Â  
Robertâ€™s personal physician, Internist Dr. Russell Hall, testified, although Robert had previously undergone some cardiac testing in 1998, he was considered at low risk for a cardiac event at that time.Â  Further, while Robert had a history of transient ischemic attack, or a stroke that resolved itself, dating back to 1991, this condition was the result of a mitral valve prolapse which had nothing to do with his heart attack.Â  After review of Robertâ€™s hospital records from the day of his death, he agreed Robert had severe coronary artery disease.Â  Dr. Hall stated that if Robert did not usually secure a load as part of his usual job, and if he secured a load on the morning of July 7, he was of the opinion that the securing of the load provoked his heart attack.Â  It was his opinion that the exertion involved, which was above and beyond what he was accustomed to doing in the course of his job, had a role in precipitating the heart attack.Â  
Faye initiated a workerâ€™s compensation claim.Â  Salem Carriers denied the claim asserting Robertâ€™s death was not causally related to the work he performed and there was no unusual stress or strain involving the work that caused Robertâ€™s heart attack.Â  The Single Commissioner denied Fayeâ€™s claim, finding the evidence showed Robert secured the truckâ€™s load the day before the heart attack, and therefore Robert did not experience any unusual stress or strain on the day of his death.Â  Faye appealed to the Full Commission, which reversed the decision of the Single Commissioner, finding the evidence showed Robert secured his load on the day of his death and that he was involved in strenuous physical exertion that was an unusual and extraordinary condition of his employment on that day.Â  The Commission further found medical evidence supported a finding that the unusual and extraordinary exertion caused Robertâ€™s heart attack by aggravating a preexisting heart condition.Â  The circuit court affirmed, finding substantial evidence of record supported the Commissionâ€™s order.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  â€œIn workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder.â€Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  â€œThe final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is specifically reserved to the Full Commission.â€Â  Id.Â  
An appellate court may reverse or modify the Commissionâ€™s decision if substantial rights of the appellant have been prejudiced because the findings or conclusions of the commission are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  â€œSubstantial evidenceâ€ is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed blindly from one side, but is evidence which, when considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the agency reached.Â  Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984).Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not preclude the agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence. Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â  Findings of Fact
Salem Carriers argues the circuit court erred when it found substantial evidence supported the Full Commissionâ€™s findings that (1) the truck was loaded on the day of Robertâ€™s heart attack; (2) securing the load was an unusual or extraordinary condition of employment; and (3) unusual and extraordinary conditions of employment caused Robertâ€™s heart attack.Â  We disagree.
A.Â Â  Loading the Truck
Salem Carriers argues the finding that the truck was loaded on the day of Robertâ€™s heart attack is unsupported by substantial evidence and that Faye failed to prove Robert secured his load on that day.Â  Accordingly, it contends there is no temporal connection between any exertion and the heart attack.Â  We disagree.
First, it should be noted there was no finding that the truck was loaded on the day of Robertâ€™s heart attack.Â  Rather, the Commission found Robert was securing his load on July 7 when he began experiencing chest pains.Â  Neither the Full Commission nor the circuit court made a finding regarding which day the truck was loaded.Â  The question to be determined is not when the truck was loaded, but when Robert secured that load, which required the physical exertion by Robert.Â  
Miller testified it would not be unusual for a truck to be loaded and left overnight without it having been secured by the driver, and Doherty indicated trailers were at times loaded in the driverâ€™s absence.Â  Based on his experience, Miller believed Robert did not take possession and control of the load until July 7, when he signed the bill of lading, and that Robert spent the morning of July 7 at the RMAX plant securing his load. It was Dohertyâ€™s expert opinion that Robert was hooking up his trailer and strapping and tarping his load on the morning of his death.Â  Further, there was evidence that Robert told an emergency medical technician on July 7 that his chest pains began as he was securing his load around 8:00 that morning.Â  Finally, there is evidence Robert had been at the plant for one hour and twenty-three minutes before he left the plant with his secured load on July 7, giving him enough time to secure the load that morning.Â  Accordingly, substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s finding that Robert secured his load on the day of his death.
B.Â Â  Unusual or Extraordinary ConditionsÂ Â  
Salem Carriers also argues substantial evidence does not support the Commissionâ€™s finding that securing the load was an unusual or extraordinary condition of Robertâ€™s employment resulting in his heart attack.Â  We disagree.

  If an employee dies of a heart attack . . . he or she must show not only that the injury was in the course of employment but also that the death arose out of employment, in that it was brought about by unexpected strain or over-exertion, or as a result of unusual and extraordinary conditions of employmentÂ  However, if such an injury results as a consequence of the ordinary exertion that is required in the performance of employment duties in the ordinary and usual manner, and without any outward untoward event, it is not compensable as an accident.

Jennings v. Chambers Dev. Co., 335 S.C. 249, 255, 516 S.E.2d 453, 456 (Ct. App. 1999) (citations omitted).Â  Salem Carriers bases its appeal on the fact that securing a load is usual and ordinary for a flatbed truck driver.Â  While this is true, Robert was employed primarily in the light duty position of a drop and hook driver and rarely drove a flatbed truck for the company.Â  He was a drop and hook driver ninety-eight to ninety-nine percent of the time he was employed with Salem Carriers, having driven a flatbed truck only three days in 1998 and two days in July 1999 before the day of his death.Â  Thus, substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s finding that securing the load for the flatbed operation was an unusual and extraordinary condition of Robertâ€™s employment duties.
C.Â Â  Causation
Next, Salem Carriers argues there was no substantial evidence of record to support a finding that Robertâ€™s heart attack was caused by unusual and extraordinary conditions of employment.Â  We disagree.Â  
In order for a death from a heart attack to be compensable, it must arise out of employment, in that it is brought about by unexpected strain or over-exertion, or as a result of unusual and extraordinary conditions of employment.Â  Jennings, 335 S.C at 255, 516 S.E.2d at 456.Â  Here, Dr. Hall testified that if Robert did not usually secure a load as part of his usual job, and if he secured a load on the morning of July 7, he was of the opinion that the securing of the load provoked Robertâ€™s heart attack.Â  It was Dr. Hallâ€™s opinion that the exertion above and beyond what Robert was accustomed to doing in the course of his job had a role in precipitating his heart attack.Â  Further, the doctor who treated Robert at the hospital the morning he had the heart attack, Dr. Cebe, testified, in order to correlate a heart attack with extreme exertion, there must be a temporal relationship between the exertion and the onset of symptoms.Â  Dr. Cebe further stated unusual physical exertion can trigger a heart attack, and he was of the opinion, assuming the level of physical exertion described and based on what he had seen in Robertâ€™s medical records, that Robertâ€™s heart attack was related to the physical exertion he experienced at 8:00 on the morning of his death.Â  
We hold substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s finding that Robert was involved in strenuous physical exertion that was an unusual and extraordinary condition of his employment and that the unusual and extraordinary exertion caused Robertâ€™s heart attack by aggravating a preexisting heart condition.
II.Â Â  Error of Law
Finally, Salem Carriers argues Faye did not meet her burden of proof, and therefore, the award of benefits was an error of law.Â  It argues whatever Robert was doing on the morning of his death was sheer speculation, and therefore the claim must fail.Â  We disagree.
The Full Commission found that (1) Robert was securing his load on July 7 when he began having chest pain; (2) as a substitute flatbed truck driver, Robert was engaged in strenuous physical exertion that was an unusual and extraordinary condition of employment for Robert; and (3) medical evidence supported a finding that the unusual and extraordinary physical exertion caused the heart attack by aggravating a pre-existing heart condition.Â  As previously noted, substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s finding that Robert secured his load on the morning of his death, and that securing the load for the flatbed operation was an unusual and extraordinary condition of Robertâ€™s employment duties.Â  The record also contains substantial evidence that the unusual and extraordinary exertion caused Robertâ€™s heart attack by aggravating a preexisting heart condition.Â  Accordingly, Faye met the burden of proof required for a heart attack to be compensable. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the forgoing, we find the Commissionâ€™s findings of fact were supported by substantial evidence and that Faye met her burden of proving her husbandâ€™s heart attack was compensable.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court affirming the award of benefits is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., AND HUFF AND BEATTY, JJ., concur.
